data
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: There are a lot of nouns in English of Latin or Greek origin. Ó¢ÓïÃû´ÊÖĞÓĞºÜ¶àÀ´×ÔÀ­¶¡Óï»òÏ£À°Óï. They often end in -us, -a, -um, -on, etc. ÕâĞ©´Ê¶àÒÔ-us¡¢ -a¡¢ -um¡¢ -onµÈ½áÎ². The plural forms of these nouns can cause difficulty. ÕâĞ©Ãû´ÊµÄ¸´ÊıĞÎÊ½¿ÉÄÜ»áÔì³ÉÀ§ÄÑ.  1 Some, especially scientific terms, have kept their original singular and plural forms ÓĞĞ©´Ê, ÌØ±ğÊÇ¿ÆÑ§ÊõÓï, ÈÔ±£ÁôÖøÔ­À´µÄµ¥¸´ÊıĞÎÊ½: bacillus, bacilli *  larva, larvae *  criterion, criteria.  2 Many, especially those in general use, now only have a regular English plural form ÆäÖĞºÜ¶à´Ê, ÌØ±ğÊÇ³£ÓÃ´Ê, ÏÖÔÚÖ»ÓĞºÏºõÓ¢Óï¹æÔòµÄ¸´ÊıĞÎÊ½: arena, arenas *  circus, circuses *  electron, electrons.  3 Some have alternative plural forms, which are both acceptable. ÓĞĞ©´Ê, ÓĞÁ½ÖÖ¸´ÊıĞÎÊ½, ¾ù¿ÉÊ¹ÓÃ. The Latin form is more formal À­¶¡ÓïÊ½µÄ¸´ÊıĞÎÊ½½Ï×¯ÖØ: focus, focuses/foci *  formula, formulas/formulae *  spectrum, spectrums/spectra.  4 There is uncertainty with some nouns as to whether they are singular or plural ÓĞĞ©Ãû´Êµ½µ×ÊÇµ¥Êı»¹ÊÇ¸´Êı, ÄÑÒÔÈ·¶¨: This data is correct and These data are correct are both acceptable. Êı¾İÕıÈ·£¨Ó¢ÎÄ¾äÖĞÓÃis»òare¾ù¿É£©. Paraphernalia (a Greek plural) is used as a singular noun *paraphernalia£¨Ï£À°Óï¸´Êı£©Ò»×ÖÓÃ×÷µ¥ÊıÃû´Ê: All my fishing paraphernalia is in the car. ÎÒµÄÓã¾ß¶¼ÔÚÆû³µÀï. Media (sing medium) is sometimes incorrectly used as a singular noun *media£¨µ¥ÊıÎªmedium£©Ò»×ÖÓĞÊ±ÎóÓÃ×÷µ¥ÊıÃû´Ê: The media are (NOT is) often accused of being biased. ´«²¥Ã½½é³£ÔâÖ¸Ôğ, ÈÏÎªÓĞÆ«¼û£¨Ó¢ÎÄ¾äÖĞ²»¿ÉÓÃis£©.
date
/ deIt; det/ n  1 [C] (a) specific numbered day of the month, or specific year, usu given to show when sth happened or is to happen ÈÕÆÚ; ÈÕ×Ó; Äê·İ: Today's date is the 23rd of June. ½ñÌìÊÇ6ÔÂ23ÈÕ. * `What's the date?' `The 10th.' £àÈÕÆÚÊÇ¼¸ºÅ?£§£à10ºÅ.£§ * Has the date of the meeting been fixed? ¿ª»áµÄÈÕÆÚ¾ö¶¨ÁËÂğ? *`When was the date of the Battle of Waterloo? ÕâÕÅÖ§Æ±ÉÏÃ»ÓĞÈÕÆÚ. * The manuscript bears the date 10 April 1937. ÊÖ¸åÉÏ×¢Öø1937Äê4ÔÂ10ÈÕ. =>App 4 ¼û¸½Â¼4.  2 [U] period of time in history, eg one to which antiquities belong £¨¹ÅÎïµÈËùÊôµÄ£©Ê±´ú, Äê´ú: This vase is of an earlier date (ie is older) than that one. / di:l; dil/ n  1 agreement, esp in business, on certain terms for buying or doing sth Ğ­Òé; £¨ÓÈÖ¸£©½»Ò×: to make/conclude/close/finalize a deal (with sb) £¨ÓëÄ³ÈË£©´ï³ÉÒ»±Ê½»Ò× * We did a deal with the management on overtime. dear
/ dIE(r); dIr/ adj (-er, -est)  1 ~ (to sb) loved (by sb); greatly valued Ç×°®µÄ; ¼«ÎªÕä¹óµÄ: my dear wife ÎÒÇ×°®µÄÆŞ×Ó * his dearest possessions, friends Ëû×î±¦¹óµÄËùÓĞÎï¡¢ ÅóÓÑ * My daughter is very dear to me. decree
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: When talking about giving orders, decree and dictate can be used of individuals in positions of authority. Ì¸µ½·¢ÃüÁî, decreeºÍdictate¾ù¿ÉÖ¸ÏÂ´ïÕßÎªÕÆÈ¨µÄ¸öÈË. Decree usually suggests the public announcement of a decision made by a ruler or government without consulting others *decreeÍ¨³£Ö¸Í³ÖÎÕß»òÕş¸®²»Óë±ğÈËÉÌÒé¶ø¹«¿ªĞû²¼µÄ¾ö¶¨: The dictator decreed that his birthday would be a public holiday. ¸Ã¶À²ÃÕß·¢²¼ÃüÁî, ½«ÆäÉúÈÕ¶¨Îª¹«ÖÚ¼ÙÆÚ. Dictate indicates people using their power over others *dictateÓÃÒÔÖ¸ÈËÓÃÈ¨Á¦Ö§ÅäËûÈË: Her skills were in such demand that she could dictate her own salary. ËıÒòÆä¼¼ÊõÆæ»õ¿É¾Ó, ¹Ê¿ÉÒÔÖ÷Ô××Ô¼ºµÄĞ½½ğ´ıÓö. Ordain and prescribe suggest a more impersonal authority such as the law. *ordainºÍprescribe¶àÓÃÒÔÖ¸Èç·¨ÂÉµÈ·Ç¸öÈËµÄÈ¨Á¦. Ordain is formal and can be used of God *ordainº¬×¯ÖØÉ«²Ê, ¿ÉÓÃÒÔÖ¸ÉÏµÛ: Is it ordained in heaven that women should work in the home? Å®ÈË¾Í¸ÃÔÚ¼ÒÀï¸É»î¶ù, ÕâÊÇÉÏÌìµÄÖ¼ÒâÂğ? Prescribe is used of the law *prescribeÓÃì¶·¨ÂÉ·½Ãæ: Regulations prescribe certain standards for building materials. ÓĞ¹æÕÂ¹æ¶¨½¨Öş²ÄÁÏµÄÄ³Ğ©±ê×¼.

-deep

deepness

/ dI5gri:; dI`^ri/ n  1 [C] unit of measurement for angles ¶È, ¶ÈÊı£¨½ÇµÄÁ¿¶Èµ¥Î»£©: an angle of ninety degrees (90), ie a right angle 90¶È½Ç£¨Ö±½Ç£© * one degree of latitude, ie about 69 miles Î³¶ÈµÄ1¶È£¨Ô¼69Ó¢Àï£©. =>App 5 ¼û¸½Â¼5.  2 [C] (abbr ËõĞ´ deg) unit of measurement for temperature ¶È, ¶ÈÊı£¨ÎÂ¶ÈµÄÁ¿¶Èµ¥Î»£©: Water freezes at 32 degrees Fahrenheit (32 F) or zero/nought degrees Celsius (0 C). demonstration
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨:  1 A demonstration and a display do not require a specific or permanent site.*demonstrationºÍdisplay²»±ØÓĞÌØ¶¨µÄ»òÓÀ¾ÃµÄµØµã. demonstrative
/ dI5mCnstrEtIv; dI`mBnstrEtIv/ adj  1 (a) (of people) showing the feelings readily £¨Ö¸ÈË£©Ò×Á÷Â¶¸ĞÇéµÄ, Ï²Å­ĞÎì¶É«µÄ: Some people are more demonstrative than others. ÓĞĞ©ÈË½Ï°®Á÷Â¶¸ĞÇé. ËûÈÈÇé±¼·Å, ÎÇÁËÎÒµÄË«¼Õ.  2 (grammar) (of a determiner or pronoun) indicating the person or thing referred to £¨Ö¸ÏŞ¶¨´Ê»ò´ú´Ê£©Ö¸Ê¾µÄ: In `This is my bike', `this' is a demonstrative pronoun. ÔÚThis is my bikeÒ»¾äÖĞ, thisÊÇÖ¸Ê¾´ú´Ê. > demonstratively adv. demonstrativeness n [U]: embarrassed by demonstrativeness ÊÜ¹«¿ª±íÂ¶µÄ°®Ä½Ö®ÇéËù¾½.

depend
/ dI5pend; dI`pZnd/ v  1 (idm Ï°Óï) that de`pends; it (all) de`pends (used alone, or at the beginning of a sentence µ¥¶ÀÊ¹ÓÃ, »òÓÃì¶¾äÊ×) the result will be decided by sth mentioned or implied ÄÇµÃ¿´Çé¿ö: `Can I come?' `That depends: there might not be room in the car.' £àÎÒÄÜÀ´Âğ?£§£àÄÇÒª¿´Çé¿ö, Æû³µÀï¿ÉÄÜÃ»ÓĞ¿Õ×ùÁË.£§ * It depends how you tackle the problem. ËıÊÇ¸ö¿ÉÒÔĞÅÀµµÄÈË. depend on sb/sth (for sth) (usu not in the continuous tenses Í¨³£²»ÓÃì¶½øĞĞÊ±Ì¬) (a) need sb/sth for a particular purpose £¨ÒòÄ³Ä¿µÄ£©ĞèÒªÄ³ÈË[Ä³ÊÂÎï]: I haven't got a car, so I have to depend on the buses. deposit account

ÔÚÕâ·½Ãæ, ·¨Óï²»Í¬ì¶Ó¢Óï[·¨ÓïÓëÓ¢ÓïÓĞÇø±ğ].  2 ~ (with/from sb) (about/on sth) disagree; not share the same opinion ²»Í¬Òâ; ³ÖÒìÒé: I'm sorry to differ with you on that. ¶Ô²»Æğ, ÔÚÄÇÒ»µãÉÏÎÒÓëÄã¿´·¨²»Í¬. * We differ on many things. difference
/ 5dIfrEns; `dIfrEns/ n  1 [C] ~ (between A and B); ~ (in/of sth) state or way in which two people or things are not the same, or in which sb/sth has changed ²î±ğ; ²îÒì; ²»Í¬Ö®´¦; ±ä»¯; ±ä»¯Ö®´¦: the marked differences between the two children Á½¸öº¢×ÓÖ®¼äµÄÏÔÖø²î±ğ * Did you notice a difference (in her)? different
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: British and US English differ as regards the prepositions used after different. ½ÓÔÚdifferentááÃæµÄ½é´Ê, ÔÚÓ¢Ê½Ó¢ÓïºÍÃÀÊ½Ó¢ÓïÖĞÓĞËù²»Í¬.  1 Before a noun or adverbial phrase, both from and to are acceptable in British English. ÈôÓÃÔÚÃû´Ê»ò×´Óï¶ÌÓïÇ°, Ó¢Ê½Ó¢ÓïÊ¹ÓÃfromºÍto¾ù¿É. Some speakers prefer from. ÓĞµÄÈËÏ²»¶ÓÃfrom. Different than is not usual *different thanÔò²»³£ÓÃ: He's very different from/to his brother. Ëû¸úËû¸ç¸çºÜ²»Í¬. * This visit is very different from/to last time. Õâ´ÎµÄ·ÃÎÊÓëÉÏ´Î´ó²»Ò»Ñù. In US English than is commonly used (not to) ÔÚÃÀÊ½Ó¢ÓïÖĞ, thanÊ¹ÓÃµÃ½ÏÆÕ±é£¨toÔò²»³£¼û£©: Your trains are different from/than ours. ÄãÃÇµÄ»ğ³µ¸úÎÒÃÇµÄ²»Ò»Ñù. * You look different than before. Äã¿´ÉÏÈ¥¸ú´ÓÇ°²»Í¬ÁË.  2 In both varieties, but especially in US English, than is an alternative to from before a clause ÔÚÒÔÉÏÁ½ÖÖÓ¢ÓïÖĞ, ÓÈÆäÊÇÃÀÊ½Ó¢Óï, ´Ó¾äÇ°¼È¿ÉÓÃfromÒà¿ÉÓÃthan: His appearance was very different from what I'd expected/His appearance was very different than I'd expected. ËûµÄÈİÃ²ÓëÎÒÏëÏñµÄÏàÈ¥ÉõÔ¶.

differential 
n  1 (also differential wage) (esp Brit) difference in rates of pay for different types of work or workers £¨²»Í¬¹¤ÖÖ»ò¹¤ÈËµÄ£©¹¤×Ê¼¶²î: a dispute about the differential between men and women workers ÓĞ¹ØÄĞÅ®¹¤²»Í¬³êµÄÕùÒé.  2 (also ,differential `gear) gear enabling a vehicle's back wheels to turn at different speeds when going round corners £¨³µÁ¾×ªÍäÊ±Ê¹Á½ááÂÖÒÔ²»Í¬ËÙ¶È×ª¶¯µÄ£©²îËÙÆ÷. =>illus at App 1 ¼û¸½Â¼1Ö®²åÍ¼, page xii.

(mathematics Êı) branch of calculus concerned with calculating rates of change, maximum and minimum values, etc Î¢·Ö£¨Ñ§£©. Cf ²Î¿´ integral calculus (integral).

dimension
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨:  1 It is sometimes difficult to decide whether length (adj long), width (adj wide) or depth (adj deep) is the correct term for a particular measurement. ¶Ôì¶ÎïÌåÄ³Ò»±ßµÄÁ¿¶È, ÔÚlength (adj long)¡¢ width (adj wide)»òdepth (adj deep)ÖĞÑ¡ÓÃÄÄ¸ö²Å¶Ô, ÓĞÊ±ÆÄÄÑÈ·¶¨. The measurements of a room or of a rectangular area or object are the length (measured along the longer sides) and the width (measured along the shorter sides) Á¿¶È·¿¼ä»ò³¤·½ĞÎµÄÃæ»ı»òÎïÌå, ÓÃlength£¨³¤¶È, ÑØ½Ï³¤µÄ±ßÁ¿µÃ£©ºÍwidth£¨¿í¶È, ÑØ½Ï¶ÌµÄ±ßÁ¿µÃ£©±íÊ¾: The garage is 6 metres long and 3 metres wide. Æû³µ·¿³¤6Ã×, ¿í3Ã×. When describing a piece of furniture that has a front and a back, both length and width can be used for the longer sides and depth is used for the measurement from front to back. ÔÚĞÎÈİÒ»¼şÓĞÇ°ááÖ®·ÖµÄ¼Ò¾ßÊ±, lengthºÍwidth¾ù¿ÉÓÃÒÔÖ¸½Ï³¤µÄ±ß, ¶ødepth£¨Éî¶È£©ÔòÖ¸´ÓÇ°Ãæµ½ááÃæµÄ³ß´ç. Length is generally used when the measurement of the front is much greater than that of the depth. ÈôÇ°ÃæµÄ³¤¶ÌÔ¶Ô¶³¬¹ıÉî¶È, Ò»°ãÓÃlength. *Width is used when the measurements of the front and of the depth are similar. ÈôÇ°ÃæµÄ³¤¶ÌÓëÉî¶ÈÏàËÆ, ÔòÓÃwidth. (See illustration ¼û²åÍ¼. )  2 Compare wide and broad. ÊÔ±È½ÏwideºÍbroad. Wide is the more general word but broad is used of parts of the body *wideÊÊÓÃ·¶Î§½Ï¹ã, broadÔòÌØÖ¸ÉíÌåµÄ²¿Î»: a broad nose ´ó±Ç×Ó *  broad shoulders ¿íÀ«µÄË«¼ç. Otherwise it is more formal than wide and is often used, especially in literary language, to describe features of the landscape ÔÚÆäËûÇé¿öÏÂ, broad±Èwide¸üÎÄÑÅ, ÓÈÆäÔÚÎÄÑ§ÓïÑÔÖĞ³£ÓÃÒÔÃè»æ¾°É«: a broad river ¿íÀ«µÄºÓ *  a broad expanse of unspoilt country Ò»Æ¬¹ãÙóµÄ¡¢ ×ÔÈ»ÃÀÎ´ÊÜÆÆ»µµÄ½¼Ò°.

dinner
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: The use of the terms lunch, dinner, supper and tea varies between social classes in Britain and to some extent between regions. ÔÚÓ¢¹ú, ÒòÉç»á½×²ã²»Í¬, lunch¡¢ dinner¡¢ supper¡¢ teaÕâËÄ¸ö´ÊµÄÓÃ·¨Ò²²»¾¡ÏàÍ¬, ¶øÇÒÔÚÒ»¶¨³Ì¶ÈÉÏÒàÓĞµØÇøĞÔ²î±ğ. If the midday meal is called lunch, the evening meal is dinner or supper. ÈôÎç²Í³Æ×÷lunch, ÔòÍí²Í¼´Îªdinner»òsupper. *In this case tea consists of a drink and cake or biscuits in the afternoon. ÔÚÕâÖÖÇé¿öÏÂ, teaÔòÖ¸ÏÂÎçµÄ²èµã, °üÀ¨ÒûÁÏºÍ¸âµã¡¢ ±ıÇ¬Ö®Àà. If the midday meal is called dinner then the evening meal is tea or supper. ÈôÎç²Í³Æ×÷dinner, ÔòÍí²Í¼´ÊÇtea»òsupper. *In this case supper may be a light snack before bedtime. ÕâÊ±, supper¿ÉÄÜÖ¸ÁÙË¯Ç°³ÔµÄÒ¹Ïü. At school, children have school dinner/lunch at midday or they may take a packed/sandwich lunch with them. ÔÚĞ£Ñ§ÉúÖĞÎç³ÔµÄÒª÷áÊÇschool dinner/lunch£¨Ñ§Ğ£Îç²Í£©, Òª÷áÊÇ×Ô¼º´øÈ¥µÄpacked sandwich lunch£¨ºĞ×°[ÈıÃ÷ÖÎ]Îç²Í£©.

down

draw

dream
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: Several verbs have alternative regular and irregular past tense and past participle forms ÓĞĞ©¶¯´Ê¼æÓĞ¹æÔòºÍ²»¹æÔòµÄ¹ıÈ¥Ê½ºÍ¹ıÈ¥·Ö´ÊµÄĞÎÊ½: dream, dreamed/dreamt; spoil, spoiled/spoilt. In British English the irregular form (dreamt, spoilt, etc) is preferred. ÔÚÓ¢Ê½Ó¢ÓïÖĞ¶àÓÃ²»¹æÔòµÄĞÎÊ½£¨dreamt¡¢ spoiltµÈ£©. The regular past tense is more often used when it describes an action that lasts some time ÃèÊö¶¯×÷ÑÓĞøÒ»¶ÎÊ±¼äÊ±, ¶àÓÃ¹æÔòµÄ¹ıÈ¥Ê½: He learnt his lesson. ËûµÃµ½ÁË½ÌÑµ. *  She learned a lot about life from her mother. Ëı´ÓÄ¸Ç×ÄÇÀïÑ§µ½²»ÉÙ×öÈËµÄµÀÀí. *  He leant against the post and it broke. ËûÍù¸Ë×ÓÉÏÒ»ÒĞ, ¸Ë×Ó¾Í¶ÏÁË. *  He leaned out of the window watching the parade. Ëû´Ó´°¿ÚÌ½³öÉí¿´ÓÎĞĞ. In US English there is a preference for the regular past tense and past participle forms (dreamed, spoiled, etc). ÔÚÃÀÊ½Ó¢ÓïÖĞ¶àÓÃ¹æÔòµÄ¹ıÈ¥Ê½ºÍ¹ıÈ¥·Ö´ÊµÄĞÎÊ½£¨dreamed¡¢ spoiledµÈ£©. In both British and US English the irregular form of the past participle is found in adjectival uses ÔÚÓ¢Ê½Ó¢ÓïºÍÃÀÊ½Ó¢ÓïÖĞ, ¹ıÈ¥·Ö´ÊµÄ²»¹æÔòĞÎÊ½×÷ĞÎÈİ´ÊÓÃ: a spoilt child ³è»µÁËµÄº¢×Ó * spilt milk ÆÃÈ÷ÁËµÄÅ£ÄÌ *  a misspelt word Æ´´íµÄ×Ö.

drip
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: Drip, leak, ooze, run, seep indicate the way in which a liquid escapes from a container or tap. *drip¡¢ leak¡¢ ooze¡¢ run¡¢ seep¶¼±íÊ¾ÒºÌå´ÓÈİÆ÷»ò»îÃÅÁ÷³öµÄ·½Ê½. Ë®´Ó¹ÜÖĞµÎÂä. The pipe is dripping (water). ¹Ü×ÓÔÚµÎ£¨Ë®£©ÄØ.  2 Leak = (allow sth to) get out (through a hole in sth) *leak = £¨Ê¹Ä³Îï´Ó¿×ÖĞ£©Â©³ö: Wine is leaking from the barrel. ¾Æ×ÔÍ°ÖĞÉøÂ©³öÀ´. Ñª´ÓÉË¿ÚÂıÂıÁ÷³ö. The wound is oozing (blood). ÉË¿ÚÔÚ³öÑª.  4 Run = (allow sth to) flow continuously (from sth) *run = £¨Ê¹Ä³Îï£©Á¬Ğø²»¶ÏÁ÷³ö: Water is running from the tap. Ë®´ÓÁúÍ·ÖĞÁ÷³ö. due
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨:  1 Some speakers are careful to use due to only after the verb be ÓĞĞ©ËµÓ¢ÓïµÄÈËÓÃdue toÒ»´ÊºÜ½÷É÷, ½ö½«Ö®ÓÃì¶¶¯´ÊÖ®áá: His lateness was due to the very heavy traffic on the motorway. Ëû³Ùµ½ÊÇÒò¸ßËÙ¹«Â·ÉÏ³µÁ¾¹ı¶àËùÖÂ. But it is also generally considered acceptable today as a synonym for owing to, which is used differently µ«Ä¿Ç°ÆÕ±éÈÏÎª¿É½«due to¿´×÷ÊÇowing toµÄÍ¬Òå´Ê, ¶øowing toµÄÓÃ·¨ÓëÖ®ÓĞ±ğ: He was late owing to/due to the very heavy traffic. Ëû³Ùµ½ÊÇÒòÎª½»Í¨Óµ¼·. *  Due to/Owing to the heavy traffic, he was late. Òò½»Í¨Óµ¼·, Ëû³Ùµ½ÁË.  2 Due to can be used immediately after a noun *due to¿ÉÖ±½ÓÓÃì¶Ãû´ÊÖ®áá: Accidents due to driving at high speed were very common that weekend. ÔÚÄÇ¸öÖÜÄ©Òò¸ßËÙ¼İÊ»Ôì³ÉµÄ½»Í¨ÊÂ¹ÊºÜ¶à.

data
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: There are a lot of nouns in English of Latin or Greek origin. Ó¢ÓïÃû´ÊÖĞÓĞºÜ¶àÀ´×ÔÀ­¶¡Óï»òÏ£À°Óï. They often end in -us, -a, -um, -on, etc. ÕâĞ©´Ê¶àÒÔ-us¡¢ -a¡¢ -um¡¢ -onµÈ½áÎ². The plural forms of these nouns can cause difficulty. ÕâĞ©Ãû´ÊµÄ¸´ÊıĞÎÊ½¿ÉÄÜ»áÔì³ÉÀ§ÄÑ.  1 Some, especially scientific terms, have kept their original singular and plural forms ÓĞĞ©´Ê, ÌØ±ğÊÇ¿ÆÑ§ÊõÓï, ÈÔ±£ÁôÖøÔ­À´µÄµ¥¸´ÊıĞÎÊ½: bacillus, bacilli *  larva, larvae *  criterion, criteria.  2 Many, especially those in general use, now only have a regular English plural form ÆäÖĞºÜ¶à´Ê, ÌØ±ğÊÇ³£ÓÃ´Ê, ÏÖÔÚÖ»ÓĞºÏºõÓ¢Óï¹æÔòµÄ¸´ÊıĞÎÊ½: arena, arenas *  circus, circuses *  electron, electrons.  3 Some have alternative plural forms, which are both acceptable. ÓĞĞ©´Ê, ÓĞÁ½ÖÖ¸´ÊıĞÎÊ½, ¾ù¿ÉÊ¹ÓÃ. The Latin form is more formal À­¶¡ÓïÊ½µÄ¸´ÊıĞÎÊ½½Ï×¯ÖØ: focus, focuses/foci *  formula, formulas/formulae *  spectrum, spectrums/spectra.  4 There is uncertainty with some nouns as to whether they are singular or plural ÓĞĞ©Ãû´Êµ½µ×ÊÇµ¥Êı»¹ÊÇ¸´Êı, ÄÑÒÔÈ·¶¨: This data is correct and These data are correct are both acceptable. Êı¾İÕıÈ·£¨Ó¢ÎÄ¾äÖĞÓÃis»òare¾ù¿É£©. Paraphernalia (a Greek plural) is used as a singular noun *paraphernalia£¨Ï£À°Óï¸´Êı£©Ò»×ÖÓÃ×÷µ¥ÊıÃû´Ê: All my fishing paraphernalia is in the car. ÎÒµÄÓã¾ß¶¼ÔÚÆû³µÀï. Media (sing medium) is sometimes incorrectly used as a singular noun *media£¨µ¥ÊıÎªmedium£©Ò»×ÖÓĞÊ±ÎóÓÃ×÷µ¥ÊıÃû´Ê: The media are (NOT is) often accused of being biased. ´«²¥Ã½½é³£ÔâÖ¸Ôğ, ÈÏÎªÓĞÆ«¼û£¨Ó¢ÎÄ¾äÖĞ²»¿ÉÓÃis£©.

ÎÒÃÇÀë¿ªÊ±Ìì¿ªÊ¼ÁÁÁË. * When day dawned, we could see the damage the storm had caused. / di:l; dil/ v (pt, pp dealt/ delt; dZlt/)  1 [I, Ipr, Tn, Tn.p, Dn.n, Dn.pr] ~ sth (out); ~ sth (to sb) distribute (cards) in a game £¨Ö½ÅÆÏ·ÖĞ£©·¢£¨ÅÆ£©: Whose turn is it to deal (the cards)? ¸ÃË­·¢£¨ÅÆ£©ÁË? * She dealt me four cards. deal
/ di:l; dil/ n  1 agreement, esp in business, on certain terms for buying or doing sth Ğ­Òé; £¨ÓÈÖ¸£©½»Ò×: to make/conclude/close/finalize a deal (with sb) £¨ÓëÄ³ÈË£©´ï³ÉÒ»±Ê½»Ò× * We did a deal with the management on overtime. decree

/ 5naIsI, 5naIsaI; `naIsaI/ order of a lawcourt that two people will be divorced after a fixed period, unless good reasons are given why they should not £¨³ı·ÇÓĞÕıµ±ÀíÓÉ, ·ñÔòÔÚÖ¸¶¨ÈÕÆÚáá¼´ĞĞÉúĞ§µÄ£©Àë»éÅĞ¾öÁî.
decree
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: When talking about giving orders, decree and dictate can be used of individuals in positions of authority. Ì¸µ½·¢ÃüÁî, decreeºÍdictate¾ù¿ÉÖ¸ÏÂ´ïÕßÎªÕÆÈ¨µÄ¸öÈË. Decree usually suggests the public announcement of a decision made by a ruler or government without consulting others *decreeÍ¨³£Ö¸Í³ÖÎÕß»òÕş¸®²»Óë±ğÈËÉÌÒé¶ø¹«¿ªĞû²¼µÄ¾ö¶¨: The dictator decreed that his birthday would be a public holiday. ¸Ã¶À²ÃÕß·¢²¼ÃüÁî, ½«ÆäÉúÈÕ¶¨Îª¹«ÖÚ¼ÙÆÚ. Dictate indicates people using their power over others *dictateÓÃÒÔÖ¸ÈËÓÃÈ¨Á¦Ö§ÅäËûÈË: Her skills were in such demand that she could dictate her own salary. ËıÒòÆä¼¼ÊõÆæ»õ¿É¾Ó, ¹Ê¿ÉÒÔÖ÷Ô××Ô¼ºµÄĞ½½ğ´ıÓö. Ordain and prescribe suggest a more impersonal authority such as the law. *ordainºÍprescribe¶àÓÃÒÔÖ¸Èç·¨ÂÉµÈ·Ç¸öÈËµÄÈ¨Á¦. Ordain is formal and can be used of God *ordainº¬×¯ÖØÉ«²Ê, ¿ÉÓÃÒÔÖ¸ÉÏµÛ: Is it ordained in heaven that women should work in the home? Å®ÈË¾Í¸ÃÔÚ¼ÒÀï¸É»î¶ù, ÕâÊÇÉÏÌìµÄÖ¼ÒâÂğ? Prescribe is used of the law *prescribeÓÃì¶·¨ÂÉ·½Ãæ: Regulations prescribe certain standards for building materials. ÓĞ¹æÕÂ¹æ¶¨½¨Öş²ÄÁÏµÄÄ³Ğ©±ê×¼.

degree

difference

different
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: British and US English differ as regards the prepositions used after different. ½ÓÔÚdifferentááÃæµÄ½é´Ê, ÔÚÓ¢Ê½Ó¢ÓïºÍÃÀÊ½Ó¢ÓïÖĞÓĞËù²»Í¬.  1 Before a noun or adverbial phrase, both from and to are acceptable in British English. ÈôÓÃÔÚÃû´Ê»ò×´Óï¶ÌÓïÇ°, Ó¢Ê½Ó¢ÓïÊ¹ÓÃfromºÍto¾ù¿É. Some speakers prefer from. ÓĞµÄÈËÏ²»¶ÓÃfrom. Different than is not usual *different thanÔò²»³£ÓÃ: He's very different from/to his brother. Ëû¸úËû¸ç¸çºÜ²»Í¬. * This visit is very different from/to last time. Õâ´ÎµÄ·ÃÎÊÓëÉÏ´Î´ó²»Ò»Ñù. In US English than is commonly used (not to) ÔÚÃÀÊ½Ó¢ÓïÖĞ, thanÊ¹ÓÃµÃ½ÏÆÕ±é£¨toÔò²»³£¼û£©: Your trains are different from/than ours. ÄãÃÇµÄ»ğ³µ¸úÎÒÃÇµÄ²»Ò»Ñù. * You look different than before. Äã¿´ÉÏÈ¥¸ú´ÓÇ°²»Í¬ÁË.  2 In both varieties, but especially in US English, than is an alternative to from before a clause ÔÚÒÔÉÏÁ½ÖÖÓ¢ÓïÖĞ, ÓÈÆäÊÇÃÀÊ½Ó¢Óï, ´Ó¾äÇ°¼È¿ÉÓÃfromÒà¿ÉÓÃthan: His appearance was very different from what I'd expected/His appearance was very different than I'd expected. ËûµÄÈİÃ²ÓëÎÒÏëÏñµÄÏàÈ¥ÉõÔ¶.

difficult
/ 5dIfIkElt; `dIfEkElt/ adj  1 ~ (to do sth) (of tasks) requiring effort or skill; not easy £¨Ö¸ÈÎÎñ£©ĞèÒª¾«Á¦»ò¼¼ÊõµÄ; À§ÄÑµÄ; ²»Ò×µÄ: a difficult problem, language, translation ÄÑÌâ¡¢ ÄÑÑ§µÄÓïÑÔ¡¢ ÄÑ×öµÄ·­Òë * She finds it difficult to stop smoking. dimension
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨:  1 It is sometimes difficult to decide whether length (adj long), width (adj wide) or depth (adj deep) is the correct term for a particular measurement. ¶Ôì¶ÎïÌåÄ³Ò»±ßµÄÁ¿¶È, ÔÚlength (adj long)¡¢ width (adj wide)»òdepth (adj deep)ÖĞÑ¡ÓÃÄÄ¸ö²Å¶Ô, ÓĞÊ±ÆÄÄÑÈ·¶¨. The measurements of a room or of a rectangular area or object are the length (measured along the longer sides) and the width (measured along the shorter sides) Á¿¶È·¿¼ä»ò³¤·½ĞÎµÄÃæ»ı»òÎïÌå, ÓÃlength£¨³¤¶È, ÑØ½Ï³¤µÄ±ßÁ¿µÃ£©ºÍwidth£¨¿í¶È, ÑØ½Ï¶ÌµÄ±ßÁ¿µÃ£©±íÊ¾: The garage is 6 metres long and 3 metres wide. Æû³µ·¿³¤6Ã×, ¿í3Ã×. When describing a piece of furniture that has a front and a back, both length and width can be used for the longer sides and depth is used for the measurement from front to back. ÔÚĞÎÈİÒ»¼şÓĞÇ°ááÖ®·ÖµÄ¼Ò¾ßÊ±, lengthºÍwidth¾ù¿ÉÓÃÒÔÖ¸½Ï³¤µÄ±ß, ¶ødepth£¨Éî¶È£©ÔòÖ¸´ÓÇ°Ãæµ½ááÃæµÄ³ß´ç. Length is generally used when the measurement of the front is much greater than that of the depth. ÈôÇ°ÃæµÄ³¤¶ÌÔ¶Ô¶³¬¹ıÉî¶È, Ò»°ãÓÃlength. *Width is used when the measurements of the front and of the depth are similar. ÈôÇ°ÃæµÄ³¤¶ÌÓëÉî¶ÈÏàËÆ, ÔòÓÃwidth. (See illustration ¼û²åÍ¼. )  2 Compare wide and broad. ÊÔ±È½ÏwideºÍbroad. Wide is the more general word but broad is used of parts of the body *wideÊÊÓÃ·¶Î§½Ï¹ã, broadÔòÌØÖ¸ÉíÌåµÄ²¿Î»: a broad nose ´ó±Ç×Ó *  broad shoulders ¿íÀ«µÄË«¼ç. Otherwise it is more formal than wide and is often used, especially in literary language, to describe features of the landscape ÔÚÆäËûÇé¿öÏÂ, broad±Èwide¸üÎÄÑÅ, ÓÈÆäÔÚÎÄÑ§ÓïÑÔÖĞ³£ÓÃÒÔÃè»æ¾°É«: a broad river ¿íÀ«µÄºÓ *  a broad expanse of unspoilt country Ò»Æ¬¹ãÙóµÄ¡¢ ×ÔÈ»ÃÀÎ´ÊÜÆÆ»µµÄ½¼Ò°.

dinner
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: The use of the terms lunch, dinner, supper and tea varies between social classes in Britain and to some extent between regions. ÔÚÓ¢¹ú, ÒòÉç»á½×²ã²»Í¬, lunch¡¢ dinner¡¢ supper¡¢ teaÕâËÄ¸ö´ÊµÄÓÃ·¨Ò²²»¾¡ÏàÍ¬, ¶øÇÒÔÚÒ»¶¨³Ì¶ÈÉÏÒàÓĞµØÇøĞÔ²î±ğ. If the midday meal is called lunch, the evening meal is dinner or supper. ÈôÎç²Í³Æ×÷lunch, ÔòÍí²Í¼´Îªdinner»òsupper. *In this case tea consists of a drink and cake or biscuits in the afternoon. ÔÚÕâÖÖÇé¿öÏÂ, teaÔòÖ¸ÏÂÎçµÄ²èµã, °üÀ¨ÒûÁÏºÍ¸âµã¡¢ ±ıÇ¬Ö®Àà. If the midday meal is called dinner then the evening meal is tea or supper. ÈôÎç²Í³Æ×÷dinner, ÔòÍí²Í¼´ÊÇtea»òsupper. *In this case supper may be a light snack before bedtime. ÕâÊ±, supper¿ÉÄÜÖ¸ÁÙË¯Ç°³ÔµÄÒ¹Ïü. At school, children have school dinner/lunch at midday or they may take a packed/sandwich lunch with them. ÔÚĞ£Ñ§ÉúÖĞÎç³ÔµÄÒª÷áÊÇschool dinner/lunch£¨Ñ§Ğ£Îç²Í£©, Òª÷áÊÇ×Ô¼º´øÈ¥µÄpacked sandwich lunch£¨ºĞ×°[ÈıÃ÷ÖÎ]Îç²Í£©.

direct
/ dI5rekt, daI-; dE`rZkt, daI-/ adj  1 [esp attrib ÓÈ×÷¶¨Óï] (going) straight; not curved or crooked; not turned aside Ö±µÄ; ±ÊÖ±µÄ; ¾¶Ö±µÄ: follow a direct course, route, etc ÑØ±ÊÖ±µÄº½Ïß¡¢ Â·ÏßµÈĞĞ½ø * a direct flight, ie without stopping or changing planes Ö±·Éº½°à * a direct train, ie that goes to a passenger's destination without stopping beforehand Ö±´ïÁĞ³µ * a direct hit/shot, ie not turned aside by hitting sth else first Ö±½ÓÃüÖĞ * the direct rays of the sun, ie not reflected from or screened by sth Ö±ÉäµÄÑô¹â.  2 (a) with nothing or no one in between; immediate Ö±½ÓµÄ; µ±ÖĞÃ»ÓĞÆäËûÊÂÎïµÄ; ²»¾­ÆäËûÈËµÄ; Ç××ÔµÄ; ×î½Ó½üµÄ: a direct result, link, connection Ö±½ÓµÄ½á¹û¡¢ ¹ØÏµ¡¢ ÁªÏµ * I'm in direct contact with the hijackers. direct

direct debit

direct object

ÔÚÕşÖÎÉÏ, ĞèÒªÊ¸Ö¾²»ÒÆ²ÅÄÜÈ¡Ê¤, ÎÒ»³ÒÉËûÄÜ·ñ¼á³Öµ½µ×. in the `distance far away ÔÚÔ¶´¦; ÔÚÔ¶·½. keep one's `distance (from sb/sth) (a) not get too close (to sb/sth) £¨ÓëÄ³ÈË[Ä³ÊÂÎï]£©±£³ÖÒ»¶¨¾àÀë: I would keep my distance from that dog, if I were you! ÈË¼ÒºÃ¼¸´ÎÒªËû²Î¼ÓÄÇ¸öÕşµ³, µ«ËûµÄ·´Ó¦×ÜÊÇºÜÀäµ­. keep sb at a `distance refuse to let sb become familiar or friendly ÓëÄ³ÈË±£³ÖÒ»¶¨¾àÀë; ²»Ô¸ÓëÄ³ÈËÇ×½ü. Cf ²Î¿´ the near distance (near1), the middle distance (middle).
distance
/ 5dIstEns; `dIstEns/ v  1 [Tn, Tn.pr] ~ sb (from sb/sth) make sb less friendly or warm towards sb/sth Ê¹Ä³ÈËÓëÄ³ÈË[Ä³ÊÂÎï]±£³Ö¾àÀë¡¢ ¹ØÏµÊèÔ¶»òÀäµ­: That stupid quarrel has distanced us. do

do
/ du:; du/ v (3rd pers sing pres t does / dQz; dQz/, pt did / dId; dId/, pp done / dQn; dQn/) * CARRYING OUT AN ACTIVITY ½øĞĞÒ»Ïî»î¶¯  1 [Tn] (used esp with what, anything, nothing and something, to refer to actions which are unspecified or not yet known about ÓÈÓëwhat¡¢ anything¡¢ nothing¡¢ somethingÁ¬ÓÃ, Ö¸Î´Ö¸¶¨µÄ»òÎ´ÖªµÄĞĞÎª»ò¶¯×÷): `What are you doing this evening?' `I'm going to the cinema.' £à½ñÍíÄã´òËã×öÊ²÷á?£§£àÎÒ´òËãÈ¥¿´µçÓ°.£§ * `Are you doing anything tomorrow evening?' £àÃ÷ÍíÄãÓĞÊÂÂğ?£§ * We will do what we can to help you. do up

do with sth

down
/ daUn; daJn/ adv part (For special uses with many vs, see the v entries. down

down

dream
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: Several verbs have alternative regular and irregular past tense and past participle forms ÓĞĞ©¶¯´Ê¼æÓĞ¹æÔòºÍ²»¹æÔòµÄ¹ıÈ¥Ê½ºÍ¹ıÈ¥·Ö´ÊµÄĞÎÊ½: dream, dreamed/dreamt; spoil, spoiled/spoilt. In British English the irregular form (dreamt, spoilt, etc) is preferred. ÔÚÓ¢Ê½Ó¢ÓïÖĞ¶àÓÃ²»¹æÔòµÄĞÎÊ½£¨dreamt¡¢ spoiltµÈ£©. The regular past tense is more often used when it describes an action that lasts some time ÃèÊö¶¯×÷ÑÓĞøÒ»¶ÎÊ±¼äÊ±, ¶àÓÃ¹æÔòµÄ¹ıÈ¥Ê½: He learnt his lesson. ËûµÃµ½ÁË½ÌÑµ. *  She learned a lot about life from her mother. Ëı´ÓÄ¸Ç×ÄÇÀïÑ§µ½²»ÉÙ×öÈËµÄµÀÀí. *  He leant against the post and it broke. ËûÍù¸Ë×ÓÉÏÒ»ÒĞ, ¸Ë×Ó¾Í¶ÏÁË. *  He leaned out of the window watching the parade. Ëû´Ó´°¿ÚÌ½³öÉí¿´ÓÎĞĞ. In US English there is a preference for the regular past tense and past participle forms (dreamed, spoiled, etc). ÔÚÃÀÊ½Ó¢ÓïÖĞ¶àÓÃ¹æÔòµÄ¹ıÈ¥Ê½ºÍ¹ıÈ¥·Ö´ÊµÄĞÎÊ½£¨dreamed¡¢ spoiledµÈ£©. In both British and US English the irregular form of the past participle is found in adjectival uses ÔÚÓ¢Ê½Ó¢ÓïºÍÃÀÊ½Ó¢ÓïÖĞ, ¹ıÈ¥·Ö´ÊµÄ²»¹æÔòĞÎÊ½×÷ĞÎÈİ´ÊÓÃ: a spoilt child ³è»µÁËµÄº¢×Ó * spilt milk ÆÃÈ÷ÁËµÄÅ£ÄÌ *  a misspelt word Æ´´íµÄ×Ö.

drip
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: Drip, leak, ooze, run, seep indicate the way in which a liquid escapes from a container or tap. *drip¡¢ leak¡¢ ooze¡¢ run¡¢ seep¶¼±íÊ¾ÒºÌå´ÓÈİÆ÷»ò»îÃÅÁ÷³öµÄ·½Ê½. Most (not seep) also indicate the way in which a container or tap allows a liquid to escape. ³ıseepÍâ, ½Ô¿ÉÖ¸ÈİÆ÷»ò»îÃÅÊ¹ÒºÌåÁ÷³öµÄ·½Ê½.  1 Drip = (allow sth to) fall in regulardrops *drip = £¨Ê¹Ä³Îï£©ÓĞ¹æÂÉµØµÎÂä: Water is drippingfrom the pipe. Ë®´Ó¹ÜÖĞµÎÂä. The pipe is dripping (water). ¹Ü×ÓÔÚµÎ£¨Ë®£©ÄØ.  2 Leak = (allow sth to) get out (through a hole in sth) *leak = £¨Ê¹Ä³Îï´Ó¿×ÖĞ£©Â©³ö: Wine is leaking from the barrel. ¾Æ×ÔÍ°ÖĞÉøÂ©³öÀ´. The barrel is leaking (wine). ¾ÆÍ°Â©£¨¾Æ£©.  3 Ooze = (allow sth to) move slowly (out of sth) because thick <SYMFONT1>, ooze = £¨Ê¹Ä³Îï£©ÂıÂıÁ÷³ö£¨ÒòºÜ³í£©: Blood is oozing from the wound. Ñª´ÓÉË¿ÚÂıÂıÁ÷³ö. The wound is oozing (blood). ÉË¿ÚÔÚ³öÑª.  4 Run = (allow sth to) flow continuously (from sth) *run = £¨Ê¹Ä³Îï£©Á¬Ğø²»¶ÏÁ÷³ö: Water is running from the tap. Ë®´ÓÁúÍ·ÖĞÁ÷³ö. due
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨:  1 Some speakers are careful to use due to only after the verb be ÓĞĞ©ËµÓ¢ÓïµÄÈËÓÃdue toÒ»´ÊºÜ½÷É÷, ½ö½«Ö®ÓÃì¶¶¯´ÊÖ®áá: His lateness was due to the very heavy traffic on the motorway. Ëû³Ùµ½ÊÇÒò¸ßËÙ¹«Â·ÉÏ³µÁ¾¹ı¶àËùÖÂ. But it is also generally considered acceptable today as a synonym for owing to, which is used differently µ«Ä¿Ç°ÆÕ±éÈÏÎª¿É½«due to¿´×÷ÊÇowing toµÄÍ¬Òå´Ê, ¶øowing toµÄÓÃ·¨ÓëÖ®ÓĞ±ğ: He was late owing to/due to the very heavy traffic. Ëû³Ùµ½ÊÇÒòÎª½»Í¨Óµ¼·. *  Due to/Owing to the heavy traffic, he was late. Òò½»Í¨Óµ¼·, Ëû³Ùµ½ÁË.  2 Due to can be used immediately after a noun *due to¿ÉÖ±½ÓÓÃì¶Ãû´ÊÖ®áá: Accidents due to driving at high speed were very common that weekend. ÔÚÄÇ¸öÖÜÄ©Òò¸ßËÙ¼İÊ»Ôì³ÉµÄ½»Í¨ÊÂ¹ÊºÜ¶à.

data
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: There are a lot of nouns in English of Latin or Greek origin. Ó¢ÓïÃû´ÊÖĞÓĞºÜ¶àÀ´×ÔÀ­¶¡Óï»òÏ£À°Óï. They often end in -us, -a, -um, -on, etc. ÕâĞ©´Ê¶àÒÔ-us¡¢ -a¡¢ -um¡¢ -onµÈ½áÎ². The plural forms of these nouns can cause difficulty. ÕâĞ©Ãû´ÊµÄ¸´ÊıĞÎÊ½¿ÉÄÜ»áÔì³ÉÀ§ÄÑ.  1 Some, especially scientific terms, have kept their original singular and plural forms ÓĞĞ©´Ê, ÌØ±ğÊÇ¿ÆÑ§ÊõÓï, ÈÔ±£ÁôÖøÔ­À´µÄµ¥¸´ÊıĞÎÊ½: bacillus, bacilli *  larva, larvae *  criterion, criteria.  2 Many, especially those in general use, now only have a regular English plural form ÆäÖĞºÜ¶à´Ê, ÌØ±ğÊÇ³£ÓÃ´Ê, ÏÖÔÚÖ»ÓĞºÏºõÓ¢Óï¹æÔòµÄ¸´ÊıĞÎÊ½: arena, arenas *  circus, circuses *  electron, electrons.  3 Some have alternative plural forms, which are both acceptable. ÓĞĞ©´Ê, ÓĞÁ½ÖÖ¸´ÊıĞÎÊ½, ¾ù¿ÉÊ¹ÓÃ. The Latin form is more formal À­¶¡ÓïÊ½µÄ¸´ÊıĞÎÊ½½Ï×¯ÖØ: focus, focuses/foci *  formula, formulas/formulae *  spectrum, spectrums/spectra.  4 There is uncertainty with some nouns as to whether they are singular or plural ÓĞĞ©Ãû´Êµ½µ×ÊÇµ¥Êı»¹ÊÇ¸´Êı, ÄÑÒÔÈ·¶¨: This data is correct and These data are correct are both acceptable. Êı¾İÕıÈ·£¨Ó¢ÎÄ¾äÖĞÓÃis»òare¾ù¿É£©. Paraphernalia (a Greek plural) is used as a singular noun *paraphernalia£¨Ï£À°Óï¸´Êı£©Ò»×ÖÓÃ×÷µ¥ÊıÃû´Ê: All my fishing paraphernalia is in the car. ÎÒµÄÓã¾ß¶¼ÔÚÆû³µÀï. Media (sing medium) is sometimes incorrectly used as a singular noun *media£¨µ¥ÊıÎªmedium£©Ò»×ÖÓĞÊ±ÎóÓÃ×÷µ¥ÊıÃû´Ê: The media are (NOT is) often accused of being biased. ´«²¥Ã½½é³£ÔâÖ¸Ôğ, ÈÏÎªÓĞÆ«¼û£¨Ó¢ÎÄ¾äÖĞ²»¿ÉÓÃis£©.
date

Õâ¼Ò¹¤³§×¬²»µ½Ç®ÁË, ºÜ¿ì¾ÍÒªµ¹±Õ. early days => early. end one's days/life => end2. every dog has his/its day => dog1. fall on evil days => evil. from day to `day; from ,one day to the `next within a short period of time ÔÚ¶ÌÊ±¼äÄÚ: Things change from day to day. ÊÂÇéÒ»ÌìÒ»±ä. * You don't know what his mood will be from one day to the next. ÕæËµ²»ÉÏËûµÄÇéĞ÷½ñÌìÔõÑùÃ÷ÌìÓÖÔõÑù. the good/bad old days => old. happy as the day is long => happy. have had one's `day be no longer successful, prosperous, powerful, etc ²»ÔÙË³Àû¡¢ ĞËÍú¡¢ Ç¿´óµÈ: He was a great singer once but now he's had his day. ËûÔøÊÇ¸öºì¸èĞÇ, µ«ÏÖÔÚ·ç»ªÒÑÈ¥. * Colonialism has had its day, ie is over. ËûÌñ²»Öª³Ü.  5 [attrib ×÷¶¨Óï] complete; absolute È«È»µØ; ÍêÈ«µØ: dead calm, silence, etc ËÀÒ»°ãµÄÆ½¾²¡¢ ³Á¼ÅµÈ * come to a dead stop, ie stop suddenly ÃÍÈ»Í£×¡ * dead centre, ie exact centre ÕıÖĞĞÄ * a dead shot, ie a person who shoots very accurately ÉñÇ¹ÊÖ * a dead sleep, ie a very deep sleep ÊìË¯ * He's a dead cert/certainty for (ie He will certainly win) the 100 metres. ËûÎÈÄÃ°ÙÃ×µÚÒ».  6 that does, can or will no longer function ²»£¨ÄÜ£©ÔÙÆğ×÷ÓÃµÄ: a dead match, ie one that has been struck ÒÑ²Á¹ıµÄ»ğ²ñ * a dead battery, ie one without power Ã»µçµÄµç³Ø * The telephone went dead, ie produced no more sounds. µç»°Ã»ÉùÁË.  7 [usu attrib Í¨³£×÷¶¨Óï] (a) (of sounds) not resonant; dull £¨Ö¸ÉùÒô£©ÎŞ¹²ÃùµÄ, ³ÁÃÆµÄ: It fell with a dead thud. deal
/ di:l; dil/ n  1 agreement, esp in business, on certain terms for buying or doing sth Ğ­Òé; £¨ÓÈÖ¸£©½»Ò×: to make/conclude/close/finalize a deal (with sb) £¨ÓëÄ³ÈË£©´ï³ÉÒ»±Ê½»Ò× * We did a deal with the management on overtime. dealer
/ 5di:lE(r); `dilL/ n  1 person who distributes playing-cards ·¢ÅÆÕß.  2 ~ (in sth) trader ÉÌÈË: a used-car dealer ¾É³µÉÌ * a furniture dealer ¼Ò¾ßÉÌ * a dealer in (ie sb who buys and sells) stolen goods ÂòÂôÔßÎïµÄÉÌÈË.
dealer
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: Dealers, traders and merchants are all people who earn money from selling goods. *dealers¡¢ traders¡¢ merchants¶¼ÊÇÒÔ³öÊÛ»õÎï×¬Ç®µÄÈË.  1 A trader works informally and casually selling household goods, etc, especially in a market *traderµÄ¹¤×÷ÊÇ·ÇÕıÊ½µÄ¼°ÁÙÊ±ĞÔµÄ, ³öÊÛµÄÊÇÈÕÓÃ°Ù»õµÈ, ÓÈÖ¸ÔÚÊĞ³¡ÖĞ³öÊÛÕß: a market/street trader ÊĞ³¡[×ß½Ö]ÉÌÈË. Õâ¼Ò¹«Ë¾ÊÇ¹ú¼ÊÁ¸Ê³Ã³Ò×¹«Ë¾.  2 A merchant sells particular (often imported) goods in large quantities *merchantÊÇÖ¸´óÅúÁ¿³öÊÛÄ³ÖÖ£¨³£Îª½ø¿ÚµÄ£©»õÎïµÄÉÌÈË: He's a coal, wine, timber, tea, etc merchant. dear
/ dIE(r); dIr/ adj (-er, -est)  1 ~ (to sb) loved (by sb); greatly valued Ç×°®µÄ; ¼«ÎªÕä¹óµÄ: my dear wife ÎÒÇ×°®µÄÆŞ×Ó * his dearest possessions, friends Ëû×î±¦¹óµÄËùÓĞÎï¡¢ ÅóÓÑ * My daughter is very dear to me. debate
/ dI5beIt; dI`bet/ n [C, U] (a) formal argument or discussion of a question, eg at a public meeting or in Parliament, with two or more opposing speakers, and often ending in a vote £¨ÕıÊ½µÄ£©±çÂÛ, ÌÖÂÛ£¨ÈçÔÚ¹«ÖÚ¼¯»á»òÒé»áÖĞ, ³£ÒÔ±í¾ö½áÊø£©: After a long debate, the House of Commons approved the bill. ¾­¹ı³¤Ê±¼äµÄ±çÂÛ, ÏÂÒéÔºÍ¨¹ıÁËÒé°¸. * to open the debate, ie be the first to speak ¿ªÊ¼±çÂÛ£¨µÚÒ»¸ö·¢ÑÔ£© * the motion under debate, ie being discussed ÔÚ±çÂÛÖĞµÄ¶¯Òé. (b) argument or discussion in general £¨Ò»°ãĞÔµÄ£©±çÂÛ, ÌÖÂÛ: After much debate, we decided to move to Oxford. ÎÒÃÇ¾­³ä·ÖÌÖÂÛ¾ö¶¨Ç¨ÍùÅ£½ò. * We had long debates at college about politics. debate

ËûÃÇÕùÂÛÊÇ·ñ¹Ø±Õ¹¤³§.  2 [Tn, Tw, Tg] think (sth) over in order to decide ¿¼ÂÇ£¨Ä³ÊÂÎï£©ÒÔ¾ö¶¨: I debated it for a while, then decided not to go. decree
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: When talking about giving orders, decree and dictate can be used of individuals in positions of authority. Ì¸µ½·¢ÃüÁî, decreeºÍdictate¾ù¿ÉÖ¸ÏÂ´ïÕßÎªÕÆÈ¨µÄ¸öÈË. Decree usually suggests the public announcement of a decision made by a ruler or government without consulting others *decreeÍ¨³£Ö¸Í³ÖÎÕß»òÕş¸®²»Óë±ğÈËÉÌÒé¶ø¹«¿ªĞû²¼µÄ¾ö¶¨: The dictator decreed that his birthday would be a public holiday. ¸Ã¶À²ÃÕß·¢²¼ÃüÁî, ½«ÆäÉúÈÕ¶¨Îª¹«ÖÚ¼ÙÆÚ. Dictate indicates people using their power over others *dictateÓÃÒÔÖ¸ÈËÓÃÈ¨Á¦Ö§ÅäËûÈË: Her skills were in such demand that she could dictate her own salary. ËıÒòÆä¼¼ÊõÆæ»õ¿É¾Ó, ¹Ê¿ÉÒÔÖ÷Ô××Ô¼ºµÄĞ½½ğ´ıÓö. Ordain and prescribe suggest a more impersonal authority such as the law. *ordainºÍprescribe¶àÓÃÒÔÖ¸Èç·¨ÂÉµÈ·Ç¸öÈËµÄÈ¨Á¦. Ordain is formal and can be used of God *ordainº¬×¯ÖØÉ«²Ê, ¿ÉÓÃÒÔÖ¸ÉÏµÛ: Is it ordained in heaven that women should work in the home? Å®ÈË¾Í¸ÃÔÚ¼ÒÀï¸É»î¶ù, ÕâÊÇÉÏÌìµÄÖ¼ÒâÂğ? Prescribe is used of the law *prescribeÓÃì¶·¨ÂÉ·½Ãæ: Regulations prescribe certain standards for building materials. ÓĞ¹æÕÂ¹æ¶¨½¨Öş²ÄÁÏµÄÄ³Ğ©±ê×¼.

demonstration
/ 9demEn5streIFn; 9dZmEn`streFEn/ n  1 [C, U] (instance of) showing sth by giving proof or evidence Ö¤Ã÷; ÂÛÖ¤: convinced by (a) scientific demonstration ÒÔ¿ÆÑ§µÄÂÛÖ¤Ê¹ÈËĞÅ·ş * a demonstration of a law of physics Ö¤Ã÷Ò»ÎïÀí¶¨ÂÉ.  2 [C, U] (instance of) showing and explaining how sth works £¨¶ÔÄ³ÎïÈçºÎ²Ù×÷µÄ£©Ê¾·¶, ½âÊÍ: a demonstration of the computer's functions ¼ÆËã»ú¹¦ÄÜµÄÊ¾·¶±íÑİ. =>Usage ¼ûËù¸½ÓÃ·¨.  3 [C] ~ (against/in favour of sb/sth) public, often organized, rally or march protesting against or supporting sb/sth £¨¿¹Òé»òÓµ»¤Ä³ÈË[Ä³ÊÂ], ³£ÎªÓĞ×éÖ¯µÄ£©¼¯»á»òÓÎĞĞ: a mass demonstration in support of the regime Óµ»¤¸ÃÕşÈ¨µÄÈºÖÚ¼¯»á.  4 [C] outward sign; example ±íÏÖ; ±íÊ¾; ÊµÀı: a demonstration of affection, eg embracing sb °®µÄ±íÊ¾£¨ÈçÓµ±§Ä³ÈË£© * a clear demonstration of their intentions ËûÃÇÃ÷ÏÔ±íÊ¾ÒâÍ¼.
demonstration
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨:  1 A demonstration and a display do not require a specific or permanent site.*demonstrationºÍdisplay²»±ØÓĞÌØ¶¨µÄ»òÓÀ¾ÃµÄµØµã. At a demonstration one sees how something works or is done ÔÚdemonstrationÖĞ¿ÉÒÔ¿´µ½Ä³ÊÂÎïµÄ²Ù×÷ÇéĞÎ: a cookery demonstration Åëâ¿±íÑİ *  a demonstration of a new car ĞÂÆû³µµÄÊ¹ÓÃÊ¾·¶.  2 A display is often for public entertainment *display³£ÓÃì¶¹«¹²ÓéÀÖ·½Ãæ: a flying, fireworks, fashion, etc display ·ÉĞĞ¡¢ ÑÌ»ğ¡¢ Ê±×°µÈ±íÑİ.  3 A trade exhibition/show/fair is held in an exhibition hall or centre where commercial or industrial goods are advertised *trade exhibition/ show/ fairÊÇÔÚexhibition hall»òcentreÖĞ¾Ù°ìµÄ, ÓÃÒÔĞû´«¹¤ÉÌÒµ²úÆ·: a book fair ÊéÕ¹ *  the World Trade Fair ÊÀ½çÃ³Ò×²©ÀÀ»á *  the Motor Show »ú¶¯³µÁ¾Õ¹ÀÀ *  the Great Exhibition ´óĞÍÕ¹ÀÀ»á.  4 A show can also be of domestic animals or plants, often in competition for prizes. *show»¹¿É×÷»¿ÑøµÄ¶¯ÎïÕ¹ÀÀ»òÔÔÅàµÄ»¨²İÕ¹ÀÀ, ³£ÎªÓĞ½±¾ºÈü. different
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: British and US English differ as regards the prepositions used after different. ½ÓÔÚdifferentááÃæµÄ½é´Ê, ÔÚÓ¢Ê½Ó¢ÓïºÍÃÀÊ½Ó¢ÓïÖĞÓĞËù²»Í¬.  1 Before a noun or adverbial phrase, both from and to are acceptable in British English. ÈôÓÃÔÚÃû´Ê»ò×´Óï¶ÌÓïÇ°, Ó¢Ê½Ó¢ÓïÊ¹ÓÃfromºÍto¾ù¿É. Some speakers prefer from. ÓĞµÄÈËÏ²»¶ÓÃfrom. Different than is not usual *different thanÔò²»³£ÓÃ: He's very different from/to his brother. Ëû¸úËû¸ç¸çºÜ²»Í¬. * This visit is very different from/to last time. Õâ´ÎµÄ·ÃÎÊÓëÉÏ´Î´ó²»Ò»Ñù. In US English than is commonly used (not to) ÔÚÃÀÊ½Ó¢ÓïÖĞ, thanÊ¹ÓÃµÃ½ÏÆÕ±é£¨toÔò²»³£¼û£©: Your trains are different from/than ours. ÄãÃÇµÄ»ğ³µ¸úÎÒÃÇµÄ²»Ò»Ñù. * You look different than before. Äã¿´ÉÏÈ¥¸ú´ÓÇ°²»Í¬ÁË.  2 In both varieties, but especially in US English, than is an alternative to from before a clause ÔÚÒÔÉÏÁ½ÖÖÓ¢ÓïÖĞ, ÓÈÆäÊÇÃÀÊ½Ó¢Óï, ´Ó¾äÇ°¼È¿ÉÓÃfromÒà¿ÉÓÃthan: His appearance was very different from what I'd expected/His appearance was very different than I'd expected. dimension
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨:  1 It is sometimes difficult to decide whether length (adj long), width (adj wide) or depth (adj deep) is the correct term for a particular measurement. ¶Ôì¶ÎïÌåÄ³Ò»±ßµÄÁ¿¶È, ÔÚlength (adj long)¡¢ width (adj wide)»òdepth (adj deep)ÖĞÑ¡ÓÃÄÄ¸ö²Å¶Ô, ÓĞÊ±ÆÄÄÑÈ·¶¨. The measurements of a room or of a rectangular area or object are the length (measured along the longer sides) and the width (measured along the shorter sides) Á¿¶È·¿¼ä»ò³¤·½ĞÎµÄÃæ»ı»òÎïÌå, ÓÃlength£¨³¤¶È, ÑØ½Ï³¤µÄ±ßÁ¿µÃ£©ºÍwidth£¨¿í¶È, ÑØ½Ï¶ÌµÄ±ßÁ¿µÃ£©±íÊ¾: The garage is 6 metres long and 3 metres wide. Æû³µ·¿³¤6Ã×, ¿í3Ã×. When describing a piece of furniture that has a front and a back, both length and width can be used for the longer sides and depth is used for the measurement from front to back. ÔÚĞÎÈİÒ»¼şÓĞÇ°ááÖ®·ÖµÄ¼Ò¾ßÊ±, lengthºÍwidth¾ù¿ÉÓÃÒÔÖ¸½Ï³¤µÄ±ß, ¶ødepth£¨Éî¶È£©ÔòÖ¸´ÓÇ°Ãæµ½ááÃæµÄ³ß´ç. Length is generally used when the measurement of the front is much greater than that of the depth. ÈôÇ°ÃæµÄ³¤¶ÌÔ¶Ô¶³¬¹ıÉî¶È, Ò»°ãÓÃlength. *Width is used when the measurements of the front and of the depth are similar. ÈôÇ°ÃæµÄ³¤¶ÌÓëÉî¶ÈÏàËÆ, ÔòÓÃwidth. (See illustration ¼û²åÍ¼. )  2 Compare wide and broad. ÊÔ±È½ÏwideºÍbroad. Wide is the more general word but broad is used of parts of the body *wideÊÊÓÃ·¶Î§½Ï¹ã, broadÔòÌØÖ¸ÉíÌåµÄ²¿Î»: a broad nose ´ó±Ç×Ó *  broad shoulders ¿íÀ«µÄË«¼ç. Otherwise it is more formal than wide and is often used, especially in literary language, to describe features of the landscape ÔÚÆäËûÇé¿öÏÂ, broad±Èwide¸üÎÄÑÅ, ÓÈÆäÔÚÎÄÑ§ÓïÑÔÖĞ³£ÓÃÒÔÃè»æ¾°É«: a broad river ¿íÀ«µÄºÓ *  a broad expanse of unspoilt country Ò»Æ¬¹ãÙóµÄ¡¢ ×ÔÈ»ÃÀÎ´ÊÜÆÆ»µµÄ½¼Ò°.

dinner
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: The use of the terms lunch, dinner, supper and tea varies between social classes in Britain and to some extent between regions. ÔÚÓ¢¹ú, ÒòÉç»á½×²ã²»Í¬, lunch¡¢ dinner¡¢ supper¡¢ teaÕâËÄ¸ö´ÊµÄÓÃ·¨Ò²²»¾¡ÏàÍ¬, ¶øÇÒÔÚÒ»¶¨³Ì¶ÈÉÏÒàÓĞµØÇøĞÔ²î±ğ. If the midday meal is called lunch, the evening meal is dinner or supper. / dI5stIl; dI`stIl/ v (-ll-)  1 [Tn, Tn.pr] ~ sth (from sth) (a) turn (a liquid) to vapour by heating, then collect the drops of liquid that condense from the vapour when cooled ÕôÁó: distil fresh water from sea-water ÓÃÕôÁó·¨´Óº£Ë®ÖĞÖÆÈ¡µ­Ë®. down
/ daUn; daJn/ adv part (For special uses with many vs, see the v entries. drain
/ dreIn; dren/ v  1 [I, Ipr, Ip, Tn, Tn.pr, Tn.p] ~ (sth) (from sth); ~ (sth) (away/off) (cause liquid to) flow away £¨Ê¹ÒºÌå£©Á÷×ß: All the blood drained from his face, eg on hearing bad news. (b) person who does not concentrate on what happens around him, but daydreams instead ×ö°×ÈÕÃÎÕß: Don't rely on his memory  he's a bit of a dreamer. ²»ÒªÏàĞÅËûµÄ¼ÇÒäÁ¦--ËûÓĞµãÉñ²»ÊØÉáµÄ.
dream
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: Several verbs have alternative regular and irregular past tense and past participle forms ÓĞĞ©¶¯´Ê¼æÓĞ¹æÔòºÍ²»¹æÔòµÄ¹ıÈ¥Ê½ºÍ¹ıÈ¥·Ö´ÊµÄĞÎÊ½: dream, dreamed/dreamt; spoil, spoiled/spoilt. In British English the irregular form (dreamt, spoilt, etc) is preferred. ÔÚÓ¢Ê½Ó¢ÓïÖĞ¶àÓÃ²»¹æÔòµÄĞÎÊ½£¨dreamt¡¢ spoiltµÈ£©. The regular past tense is more often used when it describes an action that lasts some time ÃèÊö¶¯×÷ÑÓĞøÒ»¶ÎÊ±¼äÊ±, ¶àÓÃ¹æÔòµÄ¹ıÈ¥Ê½: He learnt his lesson. ËûµÃµ½ÁË½ÌÑµ. *  She learned a lot about life from her mother. Ëı´ÓÄ¸Ç×ÄÇÀïÑ§µ½²»ÉÙ×öÈËµÄµÀÀí. *  He leant against the post and it broke. ËûÍù¸Ë×ÓÉÏÒ»ÒĞ, ¸Ë×Ó¾Í¶ÏÁË. *  He leaned out of the window watching the parade. Ëû´Ó´°¿ÚÌ½³öÉí¿´ÓÎĞĞ. In US English there is a preference for the regular past tense and past participle forms (dreamed, spoiled, etc). ÔÚÃÀÊ½Ó¢ÓïÖĞ¶àÓÃ¹æÔòµÄ¹ıÈ¥Ê½ºÍ¹ıÈ¥·Ö´ÊµÄĞÎÊ½£¨dreamed¡¢ spoiledµÈ£©. In both British and US English the irregular form of the past participle is found in adjectival uses ÔÚÓ¢Ê½Ó¢ÓïºÍÃÀÊ½Ó¢ÓïÖĞ, ¹ıÈ¥·Ö´ÊµÄ²»¹æÔòĞÎÊ½×÷ĞÎÈİ´ÊÓÃ: a spoilt child ³è»µÁËµÄº¢×Ó * spilt milk ÆÃÈ÷ÁËµÄÅ£ÄÌ *  a misspelt word Æ´´íµÄ×Ö.

drift
/ drIft; drIft/ v  1 [I, Ipr, Ip] be carried along gently by a current of air or water Æ®ÒÆ; Æ¯Á÷: We switched off the motor and started to drift (along). drip
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: Drip, leak, ooze, run, seep indicate the way in which a liquid escapes from a container or tap. *drip¡¢ leak¡¢ ooze¡¢ run¡¢ seep¶¼±íÊ¾ÒºÌå´ÓÈİÆ÷»ò»îÃÅÁ÷³öµÄ·½Ê½. Most (not seep) also indicate the way in which a container or tap allows a liquid to escape. ³ıseepÍâ, ½Ô¿ÉÖ¸ÈİÆ÷»ò»îÃÅÊ¹ÒºÌåÁ÷³öµÄ·½Ê½.  1 Drip = (allow sth to) fall in regulardrops *drip = £¨Ê¹Ä³Îï£©ÓĞ¹æÂÉµØµÎÂä: Water is drippingfrom the pipe. Ë®´Ó¹ÜÖĞµÎÂä. The pipe is dripping (water). ¹Ü×ÓÔÚµÎ£¨Ë®£©ÄØ.  2 Leak = (allow sth to) get out (through a hole in sth) *leak = £¨Ê¹Ä³Îï´Ó¿×ÖĞ£©Â©³ö: Wine is leaking from the barrel. ¾Æ×ÔÍ°ÖĞÉøÂ©³öÀ´. The barrel is leaking (wine). ¾ÆÍ°Â©£¨¾Æ£©.  3 Ooze = (allow sth to) move slowly (out of sth) because thick <SYMFONT1>, ooze = £¨Ê¹Ä³Îï£©ÂıÂıÁ÷³ö£¨ÒòºÜ³í£©: Blood is oozing from the wound. Ñª´ÓÉË¿ÚÂıÂıÁ÷³ö. The wound is oozing (blood). ÉË¿ÚÔÚ³öÑª.  4 Run = (allow sth to) flow continuously (from sth) *run = £¨Ê¹Ä³Îï£©Á¬Ğø²»¶ÏÁ÷³ö: Water is running from the tap. Ë®´ÓÁúÍ·ÖĞÁ÷³ö. The tap is running. ÁúÍ·ÔÚÁ÷Ë®.  5 ÿ?BSeep = move slowly (through a small opening in sth) *seep = £¨´ÓÏ¸¿×ÖĞ£©ÂıÂıÁ÷³ö: Oil is seeping from the engine. ÓÍ´Ó·¢¶¯»úÖĞÉø³ö.

due
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨:  1 Some speakers are careful to use due to only after the verb be ÓĞĞ©ËµÓ¢ÓïµÄÈËÓÃdue toÒ»´ÊºÜ½÷É÷, ½ö½«Ö®ÓÃì¶¶¯´ÊÖ®áá: His lateness was due to the very heavy traffic on the motorway. Ëû³Ùµ½ÊÇÒò¸ßËÙ¹«Â·ÉÏ³µÁ¾¹ı¶àËùÖÂ. But it is also generally considered acceptable today as a synonym for owing to, which is used differently µ«Ä¿Ç°ÆÕ±éÈÏÎª¿É½«due to¿´×÷ÊÇowing toµÄÍ¬Òå´Ê, ¶øowing toµÄÓÃ·¨ÓëÖ®ÓĞ±ğ: He was late owing to/due to the very heavy traffic. Ëû³Ùµ½ÊÇÒòÎª½»Í¨Óµ¼·. *  Due to/Owing to the heavy traffic, he was late. Òò½»Í¨Óµ¼·, Ëû³Ùµ½ÁË.  2 Due to can be used immediately after a noun *due to¿ÉÖ±½ÓÓÃì¶Ãû´ÊÖ®áá: Accidents due to driving at high speed were very common that weekend. ÔÚÄÇ¸öÖÜÄ©Òò¸ßËÙ¼İÊ»Ôì³ÉµÄ½»Í¨ÊÂ¹ÊºÜ¶à.
due

data
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: There are a lot of nouns in English of Latin or Greek origin. Ó¢ÓïÃû´ÊÖĞÓĞºÜ¶àÀ´×ÔÀ­¶¡Óï»òÏ£À°Óï. They often end in -us, -a, -um, -on, etc. ÕâĞ©´Ê¶àÒÔ-us¡¢ -a¡¢ -um¡¢ -onµÈ½áÎ². The plural forms of these nouns can cause difficulty. ÕâĞ©Ãû´ÊµÄ¸´ÊıĞÎÊ½¿ÉÄÜ»áÔì³ÉÀ§ÄÑ.  1 Some, especially scientific terms, have kept their original singular and plural forms ÓĞĞ©´Ê, ÌØ±ğÊÇ¿ÆÑ§ÊõÓï, ÈÔ±£ÁôÖøÔ­À´µÄµ¥¸´ÊıĞÎÊ½: bacillus, bacilli *  larva, larvae *  criterion, criteria.  2 Many, especially those in general use, now only have a regular English plural form ÆäÖĞºÜ¶à´Ê, ÌØ±ğÊÇ³£ÓÃ´Ê, ÏÖÔÚÖ»ÓĞºÏºõÓ¢Óï¹æÔòµÄ¸´ÊıĞÎÊ½: arena, arenas *  circus, circuses *  electron, electrons.  3 Some have alternative plural forms, which are both acceptable. ÓĞĞ©´Ê, ÓĞÁ½ÖÖ¸´ÊıĞÎÊ½, ¾ù¿ÉÊ¹ÓÃ. The Latin form is more formal À­¶¡ÓïÊ½µÄ¸´ÊıĞÎÊ½½Ï×¯ÖØ: focus, focuses/foci *  formula, formulas/formulae *  spectrum, spectrums/spectra.  4 There is uncertainty with some nouns as to whether they are singular or plural ÓĞĞ©Ãû´Êµ½µ×ÊÇµ¥Êı»¹ÊÇ¸´Êı, ÄÑÒÔÈ·¶¨: This data is correct and These data are correct are both acceptable. Êı¾İÕıÈ·£¨Ó¢ÎÄ¾äÖĞÓÃis»òare¾ù¿É£©. Paraphernalia (a Greek plural) is used as a singular noun *paraphernalia£¨Ï£À°Óï¸´Êı£©Ò»×ÖÓÃ×÷µ¥ÊıÃû´Ê: All my fishing paraphernalia is in the car. ÎÒµÄÓã¾ß¶¼ÔÚÆû³µÀï. Media (sing medium) is sometimes incorrectly used as a singular noun *media£¨µ¥ÊıÎªmedium£©Ò»×ÖÓĞÊ±ÎóÓÃ×÷µ¥ÊıÃû´Ê: The media are (NOT is) often accused of being biased. ´«²¥Ã½½é³£ÔâÖ¸Ôğ, ÈÏÎªÓĞÆ«¼û£¨Ó¢ÎÄ¾äÖĞ²»¿ÉÓÃis£©.

decree
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: When talking about giving orders, decree and dictate can be used of individuals in positions of authority. Ì¸µ½·¢ÃüÁî, decreeºÍdictate¾ù¿ÉÖ¸ÏÂ´ïÕßÎªÕÆÈ¨µÄ¸öÈË. Decree usually suggests the public announcement of a decision made by a ruler or government without consulting others *decreeÍ¨³£Ö¸Í³ÖÎÕß»òÕş¸®²»Óë±ğÈËÉÌÒé¶ø¹«¿ªĞû²¼µÄ¾ö¶¨: The dictator decreed that his birthday would be a public holiday. ¸Ã¶À²ÃÕß·¢²¼ÃüÁî, ½«ÆäÉúÈÕ¶¨Îª¹«ÖÚ¼ÙÆÚ. Dictate indicates people using their power over others *dictateÓÃÒÔÖ¸ÈËÓÃÈ¨Á¦Ö§ÅäËûÈË: Her skills were in such demand that she could dictate her own salary. ËıÒòÆä¼¼ÊõÆæ»õ¿É¾Ó, ¹Ê¿ÉÒÔÖ÷Ô××Ô¼ºµÄĞ½½ğ´ıÓö. Ordain and prescribe suggest a more impersonal authority such as the law. *ordainºÍprescribe¶àÓÃÒÔÖ¸Èç·¨ÂÉµÈ·Ç¸öÈËµÄÈ¨Á¦. Ordain is formal and can be used of God *ordainº¬×¯ÖØÉ«²Ê, ¿ÉÓÃÒÔÖ¸ÉÏµÛ: Is it ordained in heaven that women should work in the home? Å®ÈË¾Í¸ÃÔÚ¼ÒÀï¸É»î¶ù, ÕâÊÇÉÏÌìµÄÖ¼ÒâÂğ? Prescribe is used of the law *prescribeÓÃì¶·¨ÂÉ·½Ãæ: Regulations prescribe certain standards for building materials. ÓĞ¹æÕÂ¹æ¶¨½¨Öş²ÄÁÏµÄÄ³Ğ©±ê×¼.

default

/ 5dIfrEns; `dIfrEns/ n  1 [C] ~ (between A and B); ~ (in/of sth) state or way in which two people or things are not the same, or in which sb/sth has changed ²î±ğ; ²îÒì; ²»Í¬Ö®´¦; ±ä»¯; ±ä»¯Ö®´¦: the marked differences between the two children Á½¸öº¢×ÓÖ®¼äµÄÏÔÖø²î±ğ * Did you notice a difference (in her)? different
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: British and US English differ as regards the prepositions used after different. ½ÓÔÚdifferentááÃæµÄ½é´Ê, ÔÚÓ¢Ê½Ó¢ÓïºÍÃÀÊ½Ó¢ÓïÖĞÓĞËù²»Í¬.  1 Before a noun or adverbial phrase, both from and to are acceptable in British English. ÈôÓÃÔÚÃû´Ê»ò×´Óï¶ÌÓïÇ°, Ó¢Ê½Ó¢ÓïÊ¹ÓÃfromºÍto¾ù¿É. Some speakers prefer from. ÓĞµÄÈËÏ²»¶ÓÃfrom. Different than is not usual *different thanÔò²»³£ÓÃ: He's very different from/to his brother. Ëû¸úËû¸ç¸çºÜ²»Í¬. * This visit is very different from/to last time. Õâ´ÎµÄ·ÃÎÊÓëÉÏ´Î´ó²»Ò»Ñù. In US English than is commonly used (not to) ÔÚÃÀÊ½Ó¢ÓïÖĞ, thanÊ¹ÓÃµÃ½ÏÆÕ±é£¨toÔò²»³£¼û£©: Your trains are different from/than ours. ÄãÃÇµÄ»ğ³µ¸úÎÒÃÇµÄ²»Ò»Ñù. * You look different than before. differential 
n  1 (also differential wage) (esp Brit) difference in rates of pay for different types of work or workers £¨²»Í¬¹¤ÖÖ»ò¹¤ÈËµÄ£©¹¤×Ê¼¶²î: a dispute about the differential between men and women workers ÓĞ¹ØÄĞÅ®¹¤²»Í¬³êµÄÕùÒé.  2 (also ,differential `gear) gear enabling a vehicle's back wheels to turn at different speeds when going round corners £¨³µÁ¾×ªÍäÊ±Ê¹Á½ááÂÖÒÔ²»Í¬ËÙ¶È×ª¶¯µÄ£©²îËÙÆ÷. =>illus at App 1 ¼û¸½Â¼1Ö®²åÍ¼, page xii.

-dimensional
/ -FEnEl; -FEnl/ (forming compound adjs ÓÃÒÔ¹¹³É¸´ºÏĞÎÈİ´Ê) having the specified number of dimensions ...Î¬µÄ; ...·½ÃæµÄ: A square is two-dimensional and a cube is three-dimensional. Õı·½ĞÎÊÇ¶şÎ¬µÄ£¨Æ½ÃæµÄ£©, ¶øÕıÁùÃæÌåÔòÊÇÈıÎ¬µÄ£¨Á¢ÌåµÄ£©.
dimension
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨:  1 It is sometimes difficult to decide whether length (adj long), width (adj wide) or depth (adj deep) is the correct term for a particular measurement. ¶Ôì¶ÎïÌåÄ³Ò»±ßµÄÁ¿¶È, ÔÚlength (adj long)¡¢ width (adj wide)»òdepth (adj deep)ÖĞÑ¡ÓÃÄÄ¸ö²Å¶Ô, ÓĞÊ±ÆÄÄÑÈ·¶¨. The measurements of a room or of a rectangular area or object are the length (measured along the longer sides) and the width (measured along the shorter sides) Á¿¶È·¿¼ä»ò³¤·½ĞÎµÄÃæ»ı»òÎïÌå, ÓÃlength£¨³¤¶È, ÑØ½Ï³¤µÄ±ßÁ¿µÃ£©ºÍwidth£¨¿í¶È, ÑØ½Ï¶ÌµÄ±ßÁ¿µÃ£©±íÊ¾: The garage is 6 metres long and 3 metres wide. Æû³µ·¿³¤6Ã×, ¿í3Ã×. When describing a piece of furniture that has a front and a back, both length and width can be used for the longer sides and depth is used for the measurement from front to back. ÔÚĞÎÈİÒ»¼şÓĞÇ°ááÖ®·ÖµÄ¼Ò¾ßÊ±, lengthºÍwidth¾ù¿ÉÓÃÒÔÖ¸½Ï³¤µÄ±ß, ¶ødepth£¨Éî¶È£©ÔòÖ¸´ÓÇ°Ãæµ½ááÃæµÄ³ß´ç. Length is generally used when the measurement of the front is much greater than that of the depth. ÈôÇ°ÃæµÄ³¤¶ÌÔ¶Ô¶³¬¹ıÉî¶È, Ò»°ãÓÃlength. *Width is used when the measurements of the front and of the depth are similar. ÈôÇ°ÃæµÄ³¤¶ÌÓëÉî¶ÈÏàËÆ, ÔòÓÃwidth. (See illustration ¼û²åÍ¼. )  2 Compare wide and broad. ÊÔ±È½ÏwideºÍbroad. Wide is the more general word but broad is used of parts of the body *wideÊÊÓÃ·¶Î§½Ï¹ã, broadÔòÌØÖ¸ÉíÌåµÄ²¿Î»: a broad nose ´ó±Ç×Ó *  broad shoulders ¿íÀ«µÄË«¼ç. Otherwise it is more formal than wide and is often used, especially in literary language, to describe features of the landscape ÔÚÆäËûÇé¿öÏÂ, broad±Èwide¸üÎÄÑÅ, ÓÈÆäÔÚÎÄÑ§ÓïÑÔÖĞ³£ÓÃÒÔÃè»æ¾°É«: a broad river ¿íÀ«µÄºÓ *  a broad expanse of unspoilt country Ò»Æ¬¹ãÙóµÄ¡¢ ×ÔÈ»ÃÀÎ´ÊÜÆÆ»µµÄ½¼Ò°.

dinner
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: The use of the terms lunch, dinner, supper and tea varies between social classes in Britain and to some extent between regions. ÔÚÓ¢¹ú, ÒòÉç»á½×²ã²»Í¬, lunch¡¢ dinner¡¢ supper¡¢ teaÕâËÄ¸ö´ÊµÄÓÃ·¨Ò²²»¾¡ÏàÍ¬, ¶øÇÒÔÚÒ»¶¨³Ì¶ÈÉÏÒàÓĞµØÇøĞÔ²î±ğ. If the midday meal is called lunch, the evening meal is dinner or supper. ÈôÎç²Í³Æ×÷lunch, ÔòÍí²Í¼´Îªdinner»òsupper. *In this case tea consists of a drink and cake or biscuits in the afternoon. ÔÚÕâÖÖÇé¿öÏÂ, teaÔòÖ¸ÏÂÎçµÄ²èµã, °üÀ¨ÒûÁÏºÍ¸âµã¡¢ ±ıÇ¬Ö®Àà. If the midday meal is called dinner then the evening meal is tea or supper. ÈôÎç²Í³Æ×÷dinner, ÔòÍí²Í¼´ÊÇtea»òsupper. *In this case supper may be a light snack before bedtime. ÕâÊ±, supper¿ÉÄÜÖ¸ÁÙË¯Ç°³ÔµÄÒ¹Ïü. At school, children have school dinner/lunch at midday or they may take a packed/sandwich lunch with them. ÔÚĞ£Ñ§ÉúÖĞÎç³ÔµÄÒª÷áÊÇschool dinner/lunch£¨Ñ§Ğ£Îç²Í£©, Òª÷áÊÇ×Ô¼º´øÈ¥µÄpacked sandwich lunch£¨ºĞ×°[ÈıÃ÷ÖÎ]Îç²Í£©.

direct
/ dI5rekt, daI-; dE`rZkt, daI-/ adj  1 [esp attrib ÓÈ×÷¶¨Óï] (going) straight; not curved or crooked; not turned aside Ö±µÄ; ±ÊÖ±µÄ; ¾¶Ö±µÄ: follow a direct course, route, etc ÑØ±ÊÖ±µÄº½Ïß¡¢ Â·ÏßµÈĞĞ½ø * a direct flight, ie without stopping or changing planes Ö±·Éº½°à * a direct train, ie that goes to a passenger's destination without stopping beforehand Ö±´ïÁĞ³µ * a direct hit/shot, ie not turned aside by hitting sth else first Ö±½ÓÃüÖĞ * the direct rays of the sun, ie not reflected from or screened by sth Ö±ÉäµÄÑô¹â.  2 (a) with nothing or no one in between; immediate Ö±½ÓµÄ; µ±ÖĞÃ»ÓĞÆäËûÊÂÎïµÄ; ²»¾­ÆäËûÈËµÄ; Ç××ÔµÄ; ×î½Ó½üµÄ: a direct result, link, connection Ö±½ÓµÄ½á¹û¡¢ ¹ØÏµ¡¢ ÁªÏµ * I'm in direct contact with the hijackers. ËıÊÇÕâ¸ö¹ú¼ÒµÄÊ×ÈÎ×ÜÍ³µÄÖ±ÏµááÒá.  3 straightforward; frank ÂÊÖ±µÄ; Ì¹ÂÊµÄ; Ì¹°×µÄ; Ö±ÑÔµÄ: a direct person, manner, answer Ö±ĞÔ×ÓµÄÈË¡¢ Ì¹ÂÊµÄÌ¬¶È¡¢ Ö±½ØÁËµ±µÄ»Ø´ğ * She has a direct way of speaking. direct
adv  1 without interrupting a journey; using a straight route ÖĞÍ¾²»Í£µØ; ¾¶Ö±µØ; ±ÊÖ±µØ: The train goes there direct. ÕâÌËÁĞ³µÖ±´ïÄÇÀï.  2 with no one in between; personally Ç××ÔµØ; Ö±½ÓµØ: I prefer to deal with him direct. »¹ÊÇÎÒÖ±½Ó¸úËû´ò½»µÀÎªºÃ.
directness 
[U] n.
direct access 
(computing ¼Æ) = random access (random).
direct action 
use of strikes, violence, etc instead of negotiation to achieve one's demands Ö±½ÓĞĞ¶¯£¨ÓÃ°Õ¹¤¡¢ ±©Á¦µÈ·½Ê½¶ø²»¾­Ğ­ÉÌÀ´´ïµ½Ä¿µÄ£©.
direct current 
(abbr ËõĞ´ DC) electric current flowing in one direction Ö±Á÷µç. Cf ²Î¿´ alternating current (alternate2).
direct debit 
order to a bank that allows sb else to withdraw agreed amounts of money from one's account on agreed dates, esp to pay bills Ö±½Ó½è¼Ç. Cf ²Î¿´ standing order (standing).
direct object 
(grammar) noun, noun phrase or noun clause which is directly affected by the action of a verb Ö±½Ó±öÓï. Cf ²Î¿´ object1 5.
direct speech 
(use of a) speaker's actual words Ëµ»°ÕßµÄÔ­»°; Ô­»°µÄÖ±½ÓÒıÓÃ; Ö±½ÓÒıÓï.
direct tax 
tax that one pays direct to the Government (eg income tax) rather than eg sales tax which is paid to the seller before being passed on Ö±½ÓË°.

dissolve
/ dI5zClv; dI`zBlv/ v  1 (a) [Tn] (of a liquid) make (a solid) become liquid £¨Ö¸ÒºÌå£©Ê¹£¨¹ÌÌå£©ÈÜ½â: Water dissolves salt. Ë®ÄÜÈÜ½âÑÎ. (c) [Tn, Tn.pr] ~ sth (in sth) cause (a solid) to dissolve Ê¹£¨¹ÌÌå£©ÈÜ½â: Dissolve the salt in water. Ê¹ÑÎÔÚË®ÖĞÈÜ½â.  2 [Tn, Tn.p] ~ sth (away) remove or destroy (sth solid, esp dirt) ³ıÈ¥, Ïû³ı£¨Ä³¹ÌÌåÎïÖÊ, ÓÈÖ¸ÔàÎï£©: The cream dissolves facial hair. ÕâÖÖ»¯×±Æ·ÄÜÇå³ıÁ³ÉÏµÄº¹Ã«. * a powder that dissolves stains away Ïû³ıÉ«°ßµÄ·Û¼Á.  3 [I, Ipr] ~ (in sth) disappear; fade away ÏûÊ§; ÏûÉ¢: All his hopes dissolved at the terrible news. / du:; du/ aux v (neg ·ñ¶¨Ê½ do not, contracted form ËõÔ¼Ê½ don't/ dEUnt; dont/; 3rd pers sing pres t does/ dEz; dEz; strong form Ç¿¶ÁÊ½  dQz; dQz/, neg ·ñ¶¨Ê½ does not, contracted form ËõÔ¼Ê½ doesn't/ 5dQznt; `dQznt/; pt did/ dId; dId/, neg ·ñ¶¨Ê½ did not, contracted form ËõÔ¼Ê½ didn't/ 5dIdnt; `dIdnt/; pp done/ dQn; dQn/)  1 (a) (used in front of a full v to form negative sentences and questions ÓÃì¶Êµ¶¯´ÊÖ®Ç°ÒÔ¹¹³É·ñ¶¨¾ä¼°ÒÉÎÊ¾ä): I don't like fish. ÎÒ²»Ï²»¶Óã. * They didn't go to Paris. ËûÃÇÃ»È¥°ÍÀè. * Don't forget to write. ±ğÍüÁËĞ´ĞÅ. * Does she speak French? Ëı»áËµ·¨ÓïÂğ? * Do you believe him? ÄãÏàĞÅËûÂğ? * Did they take you home? ÊÇËûÃÇ°ÑÄãËÍµ½¼ÒµÄÂğ? (b) (used to make tag questions ÓÃÒÔ¹¹³É¸½¼ÓÎÊ¾ä): You live in London, don't you? Äã×¡ÔÚÂ×¶Ø, ÊÇÂğ? * He married his boss's daughter, didn't he? ËûÈ¢ÁËÀÏ°åµÄÅ®¶ù, ÊÇÂğ? * She doesn't work here, does she? Ëı²»ÔÚ´ËµØ¹¤×÷, ÊÇÂğ?  2 (used when no other aux v is present to emphasize that a verb is positive ÓÃì¶¾äÖĞÎŞÆäËûÖú¶¯´ÊÊ±, ÒÔ¼ÓÇ¿¶¯´ÊµÄ¿Ï¶¨ÓïÆø): He `does look tired. ËûÈ·ÊµÏÔµÃºÜÆ£¾ë. * She `did write to say thank you. ËıµÄÈ·Ğ´ĞÅÏòÄãµÀĞ»ÁË. * Do shut up! ×¡¿Ú! * Do say you'll stay for supper! Îñ±Ø³ÔÍêÍí·¹ÔÙ×ß!  3 (used to reverse the order of the subject and v when an adv or adverbial phrase is moved to the front µ±¸±´Ê»ò¸±´Ê´Ê×éÒÆÖÃµ½¾äÊ×Ê±, ÓÃÒÔ¸Ä±äÖ÷ÓïºÍ¶¯´ÊµÄÓïĞò): Not only does she speak Spanish, (but) she also knows how to type. / du:; du/ v (3rd pers sing pres t does / dQz; dQz/, pt did / dId; dId/, pp done / dQn; dQn/) * CARRYING OUT AN ACTIVITY ½øĞĞÒ»Ïî»î¶¯  1 [Tn] (used esp with what, anything, nothing and something, to refer to actions which are unspecified or not yet known about ÓÈÓëwhat¡¢ anything¡¢ nothing¡¢ somethingÁ¬ÓÃ, Ö¸Î´Ö¸¶¨µÄ»òÎ´ÖªµÄĞĞÎª»ò¶¯×÷): `What are you doing this evening?' `I'm going to the cinema.' £à½ñÍíÄã´òËã×öÊ²÷á?£§£àÎÒ´òËãÈ¥¿´µçÓ°.£§ * `Are you doing anything tomorrow evening?' £àÃ÷ÍíÄãÓĞÊÂÂğ?£§ * We will do what we can to help you. ÎÒ×ß!  that's `done it (infml ¿Ú) (used to express dismay, anger, etc that a misfortune, an accident or a mistake has spoiled or ruined sth µ±Ä³ÖÖÔÖ»ö¡¢ ÊÂ¹Ê»ò²î´íÅªÔã»ò»Ù»µÄ³ÊÂÎïÊ±, ÓÃÒÔ±íÊ¾¾ª»Å¡¢ Æø·ßµÈ): That's done it. (For other idioms containing do, see entries for ns, adjs, etc Óëdo´îÅäµÄÆäËûÏ°Óï¼ûÓĞ¹ØÃû´Ê¡¢ ĞÎÈİ´ÊµÈµÄ´ÊÌõ, Èç do a bunk => bunk2; easier said than done => easy. )  22 (phr v) do away with sth (infml ¿Ú) get rid of sth; abolish sth °ÚÍÑÄ³ÊÂÎï; ·Ï³ıÄ³ÊÂÎï: She thinks it's time we did away with the monarchy. do sb/sth down 
(infml ¿Ú) speak of sb/sth in a critical or an unfavourable way; criticize or disparage sb/sth ËµÄ³ÈË[Ä³ÊÂÎï]»µ»°; Ö¸Ôğ»òÚ®»ÙÄ³ÈË[Ä³ÊÂÎï]: He's always doing his friends down. ËûÀÏÊÇËµÅóÓÑµÄ»µ»°. * It has become fashionable to do down traditional moral values. Ú®»Ù´«Í³µÀµÂµÄ¼ÛÖµÒÑ³ÉÎªÒ»ÖÖÊ±÷ÖÊÂ.
do for sb

down
/ daUn; daJn/ adv part (For special uses with many vs, see the v entries. Óë¶¯´Ê´îÅäµÄÌØÊâÓÃ·¨¼ûÓĞ¹Ø¶¯´Ê´ÊÌõ. )  1 (a) from a higher to a lower level ´Ó¸ßµ½µÍ; ÏòÏÂ: pull down a blind À­ÏÂ´°Á± * fall, climb, jump, etc down µøÏÂ¡¢ ÅÀÏÂ¡¢ ÌøÏÂ * The sun went down below the horizon. Cf ²Î¿´ up 1a.  2 (indicating place or state Ö¸µØµã»ò×´Ì¬): Mary is not down yet, ie She is in bed or still in an upstairs room. ÂêÀö»¹Ã»ÏÂÀ´ÄØ£¨Î´ÏÂ´²»òÎ´ÏÂÂ¥£©. * The level of unemployment is down. Ê§ÒµÂÊÔÚÏÂ½µ. * We're two goals down already, ie The other team has scored two goals and we have scored none. ÎÒÃÇÒÑÂäááÁ½·Ö. / drB:ft; drAft/ (US draft/ drAft; drAft/) n  1 [C] current of air in a room or some other enclosed space Í¨·ç; ÆøÁ÷: Can you close the door? There's an awful draught in here. Äã°ÑÃÅ¹ØÉÏºÃÂğ? ÕâÀï¹ıÌÃ·çÌ«´ó. * As the train began to move a pleasant draught cooled us all down. »ğ³µÒ»¿ª, Ò»ÕóÁ¹·ç´µÀ´, ÎÒÃÇ¶Ù¸ĞÁ¹Ë¬.  2 [U, sing] (nautical º£) depth of water needed to float a ship £¨´¬µÄ£©³ÔË®Éî¶È: vessels of shallow draught ³ÔË®Ç³µÄ´¬Ö».  3 [C] one continuous process of swallowing liquid; the amount swallowed Ò»Òû; Ò»¿ÚÖ®Á¿: take a deep/long draught of beer ºÈÒ»´ó¿ÚÆ¡¾Æ * He emptied his glass at one draught. ËûÉîÉîµØÎüÁËÒ»¿ÚÆø.  4 draughts (Brit) (US checkers) [sing v] table game for two players using 24 round pieces on a chequered board ¹ú¼ÊÌøÆå£¨Á½ÈË¶ÔÏÂ, ÓÃ24¸öÔ²ĞÎÆå×ÓÔÚ·½¸ñÆåÅÌÉÏ½øĞĞ£©.  5 (idm Ï°Óï) on `draught drawn from a container, esp of beer from a barrel ´ÓÈİÆ÷ÖĞ¼³È¡£¨ÓÈÖ¸Í°×°µÄÆ¡¾Æ£©: winter ale on draught Í°×°¶¬ÂóÑ¿¾Æ.
draught 
adj [attrib ×÷¶¨Óï] served on draught £¨×ÔÍ°ÖĞ¼³È¡£©É¢×°µÄ: draught bitter, cider, lager, etc É¢×°¿àÆ¡¾Æ¡¢ Æ»¹û¾Æ¡¢ Öü²ØÆ¡¾ÆµÈ.
draught-board 
(Brit) (US checkerboard) n board (identical to a chessboard) used for playing draughts ¹ú¼ÊÌøÆåÆåÅÌ.
draughthorse 
n horse used for pulling loads ÒÛÂí; ÍìÂí. Cf ²Î¿´ pack-animal (pack1).
draughtsman
/ 5drB:ftsmEn; `drAftsmEn/ (US draftsman / 5drAfts-; `drAfts-/) n (pl -men /-mEn; -mEn/)  1 person whose job is to make plans and sketches of machinery, buildings, etc Æğ²İÈË; ÖÆÍ¼Ô±.  2 person who can draw well ÉÆ»­Õß; ÃÀÊõ¼Ò: I'm no draughtsman, I'm afraid, ie no good at drawing. ÎÒ¸ù±¾²»ÉÃ³¤»­»­.  3 (Brit) (US checker) piece used in the game of draughts ¹ú¼ÊÌøÆåÆå×Ó.
draughty
/ 5drB:ftI; `drAftI/ (US drafty / 5drAftI; `drAftI/)adj (-ier, -iest) with draughts of air blowing through Í¨·çµÄ; ÓĞ¹ıÌÃ·çµÄ; ÓĞ´©ÌÃ·çµÄ: It's terribly draughty in here. Õâ¶ù´©ÌÃ·ç´ó¼«ÁË. 
draughtiness 
n [U].
draw

dream
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: Several verbs have alternative regular and irregular past tense and past participle forms ÓĞĞ©¶¯´Ê¼æÓĞ¹æÔòºÍ²»¹æÔòµÄ¹ıÈ¥Ê½ºÍ¹ıÈ¥·Ö´ÊµÄĞÎÊ½: dream, dreamed/dreamt; spoil, spoiled/spoilt. In British English the irregular form (dreamt, spoilt, etc) is preferred. ÔÚÓ¢Ê½Ó¢ÓïÖĞ¶àÓÃ²»¹æÔòµÄĞÎÊ½£¨dreamt¡¢ spoiltµÈ£©. The regular past tense is more often used when it describes an action that lasts some time ÃèÊö¶¯×÷ÑÓĞøÒ»¶ÎÊ±¼äÊ±, ¶àÓÃ¹æÔòµÄ¹ıÈ¥Ê½: He learnt his lesson. ËûµÃµ½ÁË½ÌÑµ. *  She learned a lot about life from her mother. Ëı´ÓÄ¸Ç×ÄÇÀïÑ§µ½²»ÉÙ×öÈËµÄµÀÀí. *  He leant against the post and it broke. ËûÍù¸Ë×ÓÉÏÒ»ÒĞ, ¸Ë×Ó¾Í¶ÏÁË. *  He leaned out of the window watching the parade. Ëû´Ó´°¿ÚÌ½³öÉí¿´ÓÎĞĞ. In US English there is a preference for the regular past tense and past participle forms (dreamed, spoiled, etc). ÔÚÃÀÊ½Ó¢ÓïÖĞ¶àÓÃ¹æÔòµÄ¹ıÈ¥Ê½ºÍ¹ıÈ¥·Ö´ÊµÄĞÎÊ½£¨dreamed¡¢ spoiledµÈ£©. In both British and US English the irregular form of the past participle is found in adjectival uses ÔÚÓ¢Ê½Ó¢ÓïºÍÃÀÊ½Ó¢ÓïÖĞ, ¹ıÈ¥·Ö´ÊµÄ²»¹æÔòĞÎÊ½×÷ĞÎÈİ´ÊÓÃ: a spoilt child ³è»µÁËµÄº¢×Ó * spilt milk ÆÃÈ÷ÁËµÄÅ£ÄÌ *  a misspelt word Æ´´íµÄ×Ö.

due
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨:  1 Some speakers are careful to use due to only after the verb be ÓĞĞ©ËµÓ¢ÓïµÄÈËÓÃdue toÒ»´ÊºÜ½÷É÷, ½ö½«Ö®ÓÃì¶¶¯´ÊÖ®áá: His lateness was due to the very heavy traffic on the motorway. Ëû³Ùµ½ÊÇÒò¸ßËÙ¹«Â·ÉÏ³µÁ¾¹ı¶àËùÖÂ. But it is also generally considered acceptable today as a synonym for owing to, which is used differently µ«Ä¿Ç°ÆÕ±éÈÏÎª¿É½«due to¿´×÷ÊÇowing toµÄÍ¬Òå´Ê, ¶øowing toµÄÓÃ·¨ÓëÖ®ÓĞ±ğ: He was late owing to/due to the very heavy traffic. Ëû³Ùµ½ÊÇÒòÎª½»Í¨Óµ¼·. *  Due to/Owing to the heavy traffic, he was late. Òò½»Í¨Óµ¼·, Ëû³Ùµ½ÁË.  2 Due to can be used immediately after a noun *due to¿ÉÖ±½ÓÓÃì¶Ãû´ÊÖ®áá: Accidents due to driving at high speed were very common that weekend. ÔÚÄÇ¸öÖÜÄ©Òò¸ßËÙ¼İÊ»Ôì³ÉµÄ½»Í¨ÊÂ¹ÊºÜ¶à.
due
